subject: fix timezone issue in test_expired_token
messages:
[{'account_id': 2340, 'date': '2012-04-16 15:06:21.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

We were getting a few failing tests because of this timezone issue. The TokenNotFound error is being raised (in keystone/token/backends/[kvs|memcached|sql] by checking datetime.utcnow(), but the tests used datetime.now()

=====================================================================
FAIL: test_expired_token (tests.test_backend_kvs.KvsToken)
----------------------------------------------------------------------
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/var/lib/openstack-keystone-test/tests/test_backend.py", line 333, in test_expired_token
    self.token_api.get_token, token_id)
AssertionError: TokenNotFound not raised

======================================================================
FAIL: test_expired_token (tests.test_backend_memcache.MemcacheToken)
----------------------------------------------------------------------
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/var/lib/openstack-keystone-test/tests/test_backend.py", line 333, in test_expired_token
    self.token_api.get_token, token_id)
AssertionError: TokenNotFound not raised

======================================================================
FAIL: test_expired_token (tests.test_backend_sql.SqlToken)
----------------------------------------------------------------------
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/var/lib/openstack-keystone-test/tests/test_backend.py", line 333, in test_expired_token
    self.token_api.get_token, token_id)
AssertionError: TokenNotFound not raised'}, {'account_id': 2340, 'date': '2012-04-17 09:33:17.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 2340, 'date': '2012-04-18 13:31:22.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 4, 'date': '2012-04-23 16:42:11.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

'}, {'account_id': 1132, 'date': '2012-04-23 16:50:21.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

The test doesn't pass for me:

======================================================================
FAIL: test_expired_token (test_backend_memcache.MemcacheToken)
----------------------------------------------------------------------
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/Users/bcwaldon/projects/keystone/tests/test_backend.py", line 334, in test_expired_token
    self.token_api.get_token, token_id)
AssertionError: TokenNotFound not raised

----------------------------------------------------------------------'}, {'account_id': 4, 'date': '2012-04-23 17:10:43.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

There's a competing patch for this (which doesn't reference a bug #), but fixes the memcache issue (which I also confirmed). Would be happy to merge this if it includes the memcache fix from below:

https://review.openstack.org/#/c/6403/"}, {'account_id': 2340, 'date': '2012-04-24 09:29:07.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: Abandoned

Ok, then I'll abandon this in favor of 6403"}]

commit_message:
Logging updates in IptablesFirewallDriver.

Update IptablesFirewallDriver so that it uses the debug log channel
when logging specifics about each firewall rule.

Fixes LP Bug #969545.

Change-Id: Ie50a3607fff17f032d577af8a87d5f4582bcc919

commit_message:
Revamp of testing machinery.

  * Uses Django 1.4 as minimum version for Folsom.
  * Switches to using Django 1.4's LiveServerTestCase instead of
    django-nose-selenium and cherrypy.
  * Moves django-nose to be a test dependency only. Fixes bug 801362.

Change-Id: I5c8a145aba868acf355fe215307d7ce8835913f6

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-04-13 19:41:20.000000000', 'message': 'Fix image-create using pipelines

The return value of ImageManager._get_file_size() is passed on to
the glance server in the create api call.  Returning None causes
the server to reject the request as malformed.

Change-Id: I02c90e2db5fbd1e49d1516550c806f26dae83fb9
'}, {'created': '2012-04-23 19:50:49.000000000', 'message': 'Fix image-create using pipelines

The return value of ImageManager._get_file_size() is passed on to
the glance server in the create api call.  Returning None causes
the server to reject the request as malformed.

Add dtroyer to AUTHORS

Change-Id: I02c90e2db5fbd1e49d1516550c806f26dae83fb9
'}]
commit_message:
Fix image-create using pipelines

The return value of ImageManager._get_file_size() is passed on to
the glance server in the create api call.  Returning None causes
the server to reject the request as malformed.

Add dtroyer to AUTHORS

Change-Id: I02c90e2db5fbd1e49d1516550c806f26dae83fb9

commit_message:
Suppress pagination on non-tty glance index.

Fixes bug 978610.

Avoid the 'Fetch next page? [Y/n]' prompt interfering with
redirected output.

The native glance CLI will soon be superceeded by the new
python-glanceclient, however this patch could still be useful
to propogate from master to the stable diablo/essex branches.

Change-Id: I16bc6156d7c7e9ed27aabcaa51211060ec24a824

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-04-23 01:04:25.000000000', 'message': 'Silence import warnings from hacking.py.

Update hacking.py so that it does not print import warnings to stderr.

We try to import potentially missing modules when running unit
tests so this error is very confusing when you do have a pep8 error.

Fixes LP Bug #980009.

Change-Id: I051d1c9d72ac63e8eb459f1a3b870677d2158e54
'}]
commit_message:
Silence import warnings from hacking.py.

Update hacking.py so that it does not print import warnings to stderr.

We try to import potentially missing modules when running unit
tests so this error is very confusing when you do have a pep8 error.

Fixes LP Bug #980009.

Change-Id: I051d1c9d72ac63e8eb459f1a3b870677d2158e54

commit_message:
Making `usage_from_instance` private.

This reduces the surface area of usage notifications down to just
`compute_utils.notify_about_instance_usage`, making future refactoring
easier.

Change-Id: If70aff191c0135c1883c39c9783f5c8433953a4e

commit_message:
Adding context to usage notifications.

This patch passes context objects all the way down to the usage
generating code. This allows that code (in future) patches to make
context-dependent calls in order to augment the usage_info dict.

Change-Id: I6592d7aecd99750cab6a91bbadc2c761155d2d4d

commit_message:
Remove __init__.py from locale dir

Previously, the __init__.py indicated that we have a custom locale package,
preventing imports of the locale package that ships with python itself.

* Fixes bug 977021

Change-Id: I5fcfb8936137b9db8a556439ca53ffeec6bbe67c

subject: Allowed the proxy to pass on the X-Timestamp header.
messages:
[{'account_id': 1216, 'date': '2012-04-14 05:31:56.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

I can't remember now why we suppressed the X-Timestamp header, but perhaps someone can jog my memory. It seems we might have just been overly cautious.

The X-Timestamp header can be *very* useful to users when migrating data, either from one account to another, from container to container, or even within a naming structures inside the same container.

GET oldlocation and record timestamp, PUT newlocation with timestamp knowing any newer object at that location will remain.

Sure, somebody could fudge up their timestamps by using crazy in the future timestamps on their PUTs (but they can already do that today).

A separate patch that might be useful is rejecting incoming timestamps too far into the future."}, {'account_id': 894, 'date': '2012-04-16 08:36:09.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

'}, {'account_id': 904, 'date': '2012-04-16 19:03:35.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

'}, {'account_id': 1009, 'date': '2012-04-19 02:44:04.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

'}, {'account_id': 330, 'date': '2012-04-23 15:57:52.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Looks good to me (core reviewer); Approved

'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-04-23 16:00:05.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Verified

Build Successful 
 
https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-swift-python26/65/ : SUCCESS 
https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-swift-python27/65/ : SUCCESS 
https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-swift-merge/180/ : SUCCESS'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-04-23 16:00:06.000000000', 'content': 'Change has been successfully merged into the git repository.'}]

commit_message:
Add distribute to test-requires.

Currently glance (which is required for testing by keystone because
there is no python-glanceclient yet) requires distribute>=0.6.24,
but it can't be installed as a dependency of a dependency.  Requiring
it explicitly here should help.

Install test-requires first, otherwise distribute doesn't get properly set.

Install distribute manually until we can re-address venv creation.

Align webob version to the other projects due to version conflicts.

Change-Id: Iac0b6860c600fbf230cf4f602ce1b76c68fcb7cd

subject: Fixed grammar and improve docs.
reviewers: [{'_account_id': 3, 'name': 'Jenkins', 'username': 'jenkins'}, {'_account_id': 330, 'name': 'John Dickinson', 'email': 'me@not.mn', 'username': 'notmyname'}, {'_account_id': 449, 'name': 'Mark Gius', 'username': 'markgius'}, {'_account_id': 597, 'name': 'Pete Zaitcev', 'email': 'zaitcev@kotori.zaitcev.us', 'username': 'zaitcev'}, {'_account_id': 1009, 'name': 'Greg Lange', 'email': 'greglange@gmail.com', 'username': 'greglange'}, {'_account_id': 1816, 'name': 'Gabriel Hurley', 'email': 'gabriel.hurley@nebula.com', 'username': 'gabriel-hurley'}, {'_account_id': 2230, 'name': 'Paul McMillan', 'email': 'paul@mcmillan.ws', 'username': 'paul-mcmillan'}]
messages:
[{'account_id': 597, 'date': '2012-04-10 20:11:55.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

I need the lines in admin_guide.rst to be folded. Re-folding in overview_large_objects.rst seems entirely pointless as well."}, {'account_id': 2230, 'date': '2012-04-10 20:49:27.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

I'm confused by what you're saying. You need the paragraphs in admin_guide.rst to not contain hard line breaks? Is this because you were having trouble with ReST formatting in the subsections? I left the code and example sections alone deliberately, even where they do pass 80 characters. The majority of the rest of that file was wrapped with linebreaks, so I figured it made sense to make the rest of it match.

I added the line breaks in overview_large_objects.rst because the majority of the file was already wrapped to 80 characters. It's hard to read and edit documentation that is inconsistently formatted."}, {'account_id': 449, 'date': '2012-04-11 00:47:35.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

I do not understand the objection above, but better grammar and clearer documentation is always a plus in my book.'}, {'account_id': 1816, 'date': '2012-04-11 03:18:32.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

All these changes look good to me.

I can't see any reason for the -1 regarding the admin_guide.rst. Those line-break changes render exactly the same as the original.

Conforming to proper reST style conventions is definitely not simply change for change's sake in any of the files here."}, {'account_id': 1216, 'date': '2012-04-12 13:42:47.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

Leaving the docs with long lines makes determining differences much easier. I suppose I can reflatten them all out on my machine to try to figure out what was changed, but why?

Changing the actually proper instances of "it's" to "it is" seems a bit silly. Actually, going around correctly all of this when not already in that file doing some other work seems a bit pointless.

I'm sorry I couldn't find a less rude way to say this, but this really seems like spell/grammar correcting people's blog posts on the internet or their email.'}, {'account_id': 1216, 'date': '2012-04-12 13:50:38.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

*correcting all of this

See? :)'}, {'account_id': 2230, 'date': '2012-04-12 18:49:44.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

I'm not sure what you mean about "hard to see the differences". Gerrit highlights the exact characters that were changed.

It seems clear that the swift team prefers unwrapped lines in their ReST. That's fine. Shall I change the patch to work the other way around then, and (in the docs I touch) unwrap the paragraphs that are currently manually wrapped? It seems inconsistent to have both styles in the same documentation file, and it seems strange to me to complain about attempts to improve style consistency.

The single correct "it's" to "it is" was done to improve the flow of that sentence. It's certainly not vital to the pull request, and I'll be happy to remove it, since this is all picking at nits anyway.

If you REALLY do take offense at the grammar corrections in the comments, I can withdraw this pull request, leave them ambiguous and incorrect, and re-issue a pull request that JUST corrects the public-facing  documentation grammar errors, without touching the line wrapping, and leaving the files inconsistently wrapped.

Which of these options would be acceptable? I'm not ok with abandoning the change entirely and leaving the public-facing documentation with known grammatical errors.'}, {'account_id': 1216, 'date': '2012-04-12 19:01:31.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: No score

I'm sorry. I was told I was being extra assy today. I'll move on as this really should not bother me. :)"}, {'account_id': 1009, 'date': '2012-04-19 16:17:17.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

'}, {'account_id': 330, 'date': '2012-04-23 15:48:16.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Looks good to me (core reviewer); Approved

'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-04-23 15:49:44.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Verified

Build Successful

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-04-03 18:52:55.000000000', 'message': "Add more to/from port checking for security groups.

Fix bug 972491.

This patch will raise an exception if a to_port or from_port is
specified, but the other is not.  This came up for me while running the
unit tests on Fedora 16.  A recent addition to nova.tests.test_api
exposed a bug in the version of python-boto included in f16.  This patch
just makes it more obvious what the error was.  See the bug for
traceback details.

This patch also removes one of the checks in nova.tests.test_api, since
it wasn't actually doing what was intended.  The '0.0.0.0/0' was
actually being passed in as a port.

Change-Id: Idf0646552cea0d86563dc0f0b59137c7966f7022
"}, {'created': '2012-04-06 13:24:14.000000000', 'message': "Add more to/from port checking for security groups.

Fix bug 972491.

This patch will raise an exception if a to_port or from_port is
specified, but the other is not.  This came up for me while running the
unit tests on Fedora 16.  A recent addition to nova.tests.test_api
exposed a bug in the version of python-boto included in f16.  This patch
just makes it more obvious what the error was.  See the bug for
traceback details.

This patch also removes one of the checks in nova.tests.test_api, since
it wasn't actually doing what was intended.  The '0.0.0.0/0' was
actually being passed in as a port.

Change-Id: Idf0646552cea0d86563dc0f0b59137c7966f7022
"}]
commit_message:
Add more to/from port checking for security groups.

Fix bug 972491.

This patch will raise an exception if a to_port or from_port is
specified, but the other is not.  This came up for me while running the
unit tests on Fedora 16.  A recent addition to nova.tests.test_api
exposed a bug in the version of python-boto included in f16.  This patch
just makes it more obvious what the error was.  See the bug for
traceback details.

This patch also removes one of the checks in nova.tests.test_api, since
it wasn't actually doing what was intended.  The '0.0.0.0/0' was
actually being passed in as a port.

Change-Id: Idf0646552cea0d86563dc0f0b59137c7966f7022

subject: Remove unnecessary power state translation messages
messages:
[{'account_id': 475, 'date': '2012-04-20 16:41:52.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

(2 inline comments)

"}, {'account_id': 100, 'date': '2012-04-20 16:52:24.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: (2 inline comments)

'}, {'account_id': 2271, 'date': '2012-04-20 16:59:39.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: (1 inline comment)

'}, {'account_id': 475, 'date': '2012-04-20 17:02:32.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

Doh, on the 3rd re-reading, I realized what you had was correct. Carry on!'}, {'account_id': 100, 'date': '2012-04-20 17:03:31.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

I can't think of any reason these messages are useful.

My original patch just removed them, but I decided to be a little cautious and just merge the messages as well as demote to debug.

There's a possibility that it's useful to see when an instance changes power state, but even then, this isn't called everywhere power state changes can happen, so you wouldn't see them all. Not to mention we don't get any instance information, so it's hard to correlate the message to a particular instance.

I think I'm talking myself into removing the messages again :)"}, {'account_id': 2271, 'date': '2012-04-20 17:18:13.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

You've certainly convinced me that the messages should just be removed."}, {'account_id': 100, 'date': '2012-04-20 22:46:54.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 475, 'date': '2012-04-21 00:14:41.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

Yay, less chatty logs.'}, {'account_id': 360, 'date': '2012-04-23 01:13:39.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Looks good to me (core reviewer); Approved

Agree this was a bit verbose...'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-04-23 01:32:47.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Verified

commit_message:
Remove unnecessary power state translation messages

The messages don't provide any extra value in debugging since
compile_info is only called in a few cases. Also, they are
anonymous and don't include information about what instance
the power state is for.

Change-Id: Ib4dae30a2e9c14d8b3bb9c47fe54742897dd3492

Hey ben - the convention when you do your git commit --amend -a is to preserve the original commit message, and then add additional bullet points on subsequent lines to describe your incremental changes.  Right now your commit message does not articulate the intent of the patch. subject: Add caching to openstack.common.cfg.
messages:
[{'account_id': 7, 'date': '2012-04-13 19:31:02.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

(1 inline comment)

See inline comments. Also, good speed improvements could probably be made within calling code as well... meaning that instead of referencing conf.<SOME_CONF_KEY> inside loops in the code, the variable should be read once and stored in a local variable and that local variable referenced in loops. It was surprising to see something like 130K calls to conf._get in the cProfile results. I would bet a large number of those could be removed by using local variables more wisely.

Best,

-jay"}, {'account_id': 708, 'date': '2012-04-13 20:07:42.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: (1 inline comment)

I don't think that such local caching is a good idea since it is module's task to provide values and with this optimization most of such local mini-caches will give no benefit at all (one dict lookup with local cache vs one dict lookup with cfg cache)."}, {'account_id': 100, 'date': '2012-04-13 21:06:16.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Do not submit

I haven't looked at the patch yet, but changes to nova/openstack/common should go through the openstack-common project first and then filter into nova."}, {'account_id': 708, 'date': '2012-04-13 21:19:09.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Created a change in openstack-common: https://review.openstack.org/6540'}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2012-04-21 06:03:04.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

code review expired after 1 week of no activity after a negative review'}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2012-04-21 06:03:05.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Abandoned

code review expired after 1 week of no activity after a negative review'}]

Add caching to openstack.common.cfg.

top-10 cProfile methods.

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-04-06 02:23:14.000000000', 'message': "Work around some proxy-connection related issues.

Firstly - apparently http urls but not https urls work through some proxies.
(Don't ask - it makes no sense to me)
Also - apparently some versions of pip don't actually honor the HTTP_PROXY
value even though they are supposed to, but do honor --proxy.
Also - SWIFT_KEYSTONE_REPO is no longer used anywhere.

Change-Id: I0bb2b2abe137525e9772301da5d2104491b12802
"}]
commit_message:
Work around some proxy-connection related issues.

Firstly - apparently http urls but not https urls work through some proxies.
(Don't ask - it makes no sense to me)
Also - apparently some versions of pip don't actually honor the HTTP_PROXY
value even though they are supposed to, but do honor --proxy.
Also - SWIFT_KEYSTONE_REPO is no longer used anywhere.

Change-Id: I0bb2b2abe137525e9772301da5d2104491b12802

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-04-11 12:00:02.000000000', 'message': "  Fixed errors in nova keypair-delete

  Description: Nova keypair-delete <keypair-name> was not able to
  delete keypairs if keypair-name consists special characters.
  It can delete every keypair-name except some keypairs which are
  having three special characters ('.','/','#').so i made some
  changes at create() in keypairs.py file.In order to solve the
  problem i doesn't allow three special characters while creating
  keypairs.nova keypair-delete <keypair-name> command can delete
  every keypair-name but not in the case of keypair name having
  above three sepcial characters.so i restricted three special
  character while creating keypairs.

  Fixes BUG 894808

Change-Id: I6f5f931ec03a94cbf71a4a6e3053453d652c7ac8
"}]
commit_message:
Fixed errors in nova keypair-delete

  Description: Nova keypair-delete <keypair-name> was not able to
  delete keypairs if keypair-name consists special characters.
  It can delete every keypair-name except some keypairs which are
  having three special characters ('.','/','#').so i made some
  changes at create() in keypairs.py file.In order to solve the
  problem i doesn't allow three special characters while creating
  keypairs.nova keypair-delete <keypair-name> command can delete
  every keypair-name but not in the case of keypair name having
  above three sepcial characters.so i restricted three special
  character while creating keypairs.

  Fixes BUG 894808

Change-Id: I6f5f931ec03a94cbf71a4a6e3053453d652c7ac8

Max_count value is validated.

Fixes bug 872615

When the user input a string value as max_count which is greater than max_quota, then nova.compute throws an exception.

commit_message:
Port ranges misleading error message is handled.

Fixes bug 914897.

When a wrong TCP port range is entered, user is warned with the below message:

Eg: euca-authorize -P tcp -p 0-65535 -s 0.0.0.0/0 default

InvalidPortRange: Invalid port range FromPort:ToPort. Valid TCP ports should be between 1-65535.

Change-Id: I96c4a3034b55de7696f7fc7fe4c0fa40b5903097

commit_message:
Add distribute to test-requires.

Currently glance (which is required for testing by keystone because
there is no python-glanceclient yet) requires distribute>=0.6.24,
but it can't be installed as a dependency of a dependency.  Requiring
it explicitly here should help.

Also, this helps standardize the distribute requirement across all
projects.

Change-Id: I346c0fb7c2203b9889b39ae8df1f8c594bbe49ae

subject: Add original_image_ref for instances and images.
messages:
[{'account_id': 475, 'date': '2012-04-19 17:05:43.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

WIP, please don't review yet :)"}, {'account_id': 475, 'date': '2012-04-19 17:09:33.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 475, 'date': '2012-04-19 18:59:02.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 475, 'date': '2012-04-19 19:00:34.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

Ready for review now.'}, {'account_id': 100, 'date': '2012-04-19 19:10:47.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: (1 inline comment)

'}, {'account_id': 475, 'date': '2012-04-19 20:51:56.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 475, 'date': '2012-04-19 20:52:57.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: (1 inline comment)

'}, {'account_id': 1132, 'date': '2012-04-19 21:40:26.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4:

Can you add a bug/blueprint for this? I don't understand what the goal is here."}, {'account_id': 475, 'date': '2012-04-19 22:09:55.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4:

bcwaldon:

Yeah good call. I'll do that too, but the gist here is that...

It's pretty useful to know what 'base-image' and instance was built off of, not just the `os_type`, but the exact image. Billing is one use-case, but there could be others.

Anyway, this field makes it easier to supply this information by point-in-time inheriting that field from a glance image-property and storing it with the instance.

We can then use the `original_image_ref` field to propagate this to future snapshots and use it in any notifications we fire off without having to do additional `glance.show` calls.

There's some debate right now in #ozone on the best way to accomplish this. We have precedent for the pattern implemented in this patch by way of `os_type` and `arch` and `vm_mode`, but an alternative would be to break these fields out into some kind of inherited image properties table."}, {'account_id': 475, 'date': '2012-04-19 22:21:54.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4: Abandoned

Taking a different tack for now; we'll probably return to this with the common-image-properties blueprint."}]

commit_message:
Add original_image_ref for instances and images.

This allows us to track the original image that an instance was built off of.

Change-Id: I9a108696b44cf1e935537366e8bfcd40ca231a3d

commit_message:
Unify different ring-balancing methods.

RingBuilder._initial_balance() gathers partitions differently from
.rebalance(), but the assignment algorithm is the same. However, there
were two nearly-identical implementations; these have been combined.

Also extracted a couple of utility methods to reduce duplication.

Change-Id: Ia5442782a8285dc14aa9a93878a7b0e8d1bb1be5

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-04-15 08:55:45.000000000', 'message': "Fixed TestObjectController.test_PUT_auto_content_type()

The test was failing silently. To catch these errors the response
from controller.PUT() is now checked.

Fixes to the TestObjectController.test_PUT_auto_content_type():
* Check for the correct 'Content-Type' header in the fake connect() method
* Pass in the correct number of responses to fake_http_connect()
* Pass a 'transfer-encoding' header to PUT() so that
  constraints.check_object_creation() passes
* Pass the correct number of elements in the 'expected' iter to the
  test_content_type() method

Change-Id: I8dced7b2f3c7e1b1d292c6995b1faf46f5e863fe
"}]
commit_message:
Fixed TestObjectController.test_PUT_auto_content_type()

The test was failing silently. To catch these errors the response
from controller.PUT() is now checked.

Fixes to the TestObjectController.test_PUT_auto_content_type():
* Check for the correct 'Content-Type' header in the fake connect() method
* Pass in the correct number of responses to fake_http_connect()
* Pass a 'transfer-encoding' header to PUT() so that
  constraints.check_object_creation() passes
* Pass the correct number of elements in the 'expected' iter to the
  test_content_type() method

Change-Id: I8dced7b2f3c7e1b1d292c6995b1faf46f5e863fe

commit_message:
Be more tolerant of deleting failed builds

Fixes bug 985705

If an instance fails to build, the xen server may not have an instance.
This can cause _get_opaque_vm_ref to unnecessarily raise an exception
and add an instance fault that is misleading.

Change-Id: I068d0af284a5671f429b2d8b13a25b629ede59bd

subject: Implement quotas for security groups.
messages:
[{'account_id': 1247, 'date': '2012-04-19 15:08:01.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Looks good to me (core reviewer); Approved

Pre-reviewed in the bug by Vish and I'}, {'account_id': 1501, 'date': '2012-04-19 15:27:52.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

No problem with the code as it stands, but can we add two additional quota values on areas which also have a big impact on the number of iptables rules that get created:

- Max number of Groups a VM can be in
- Max number of rules that can reference another group

In our experience its the N-squared impact of group rules that leads to the biggest issue in number od rules.

Folks should be able to set these to 0 to get the current behaviour (i.e. limit not applied)"}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-04-19 15:39:13.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Verified

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-04-10 16:34:15.000000000', 'message': "Make swift client easier to wrap

In the process of wrapping for profiling, a trivial wrap with def main()
ended in a ton of these:
    NameError: global name 'parser' is not defined

A closer investigation revealed an apparent confusion in argument names.
The problem was introduced by commit 985968f76550251904b64d12de025fa5d65ed03f
of November 2010. Note that Greg fixed st_delete() correctly in that one,
but apparently forgot the others.

Unit tests pass for both current (bad) code, and the patched code.
By the magic of Python scoping, current code works, just impossible
to wrap for a quick hack.

Change-Id: I18f2494ce2a201d04d49f99ea259d141939dcb6a
"}]
commit_message:
Make swift client easier to wrap

In the process of wrapping for profiling, a trivial wrap with def main()
ended in a ton of these:
    NameError: global name 'parser' is not defined

A closer investigation revealed an apparent confusion in argument names.
The problem was introduced by commit 985968f76550251904b64d12de025fa5d65ed03f
of November 2010. Note that Greg fixed st_delete() correctly in that one,
but apparently forgot the others.

Unit tests pass for both current (bad) code, and the patched code.
By the magic of Python scoping, current code works, just impossible
to wrap for a quick hack.

Change-Id: I18f2494ce2a201d04d49f99ea259d141939dcb6a

Looks great. A few minor comments. Thanks for doing this!'}, {'account_id': 681, 'date': '2012-02-29 02:44:32.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 2170, 'date': '2012-02-29 03:19:32.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

Looks great. A couple more minor comments.'}, {'account_id': 1269, 'date': '2012-02-29 05:29:07.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

(1 inline comment)

'}, {'account_id': 447, 'date': '2012-02-29 18:22:57.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: (6 inline comments)

Great to see this proposed for review, it will be very valuable to the quantum project to have this in devstack.  

A few comments inline.'}, {'account_id': 970, 'date': '2012-03-03 19:42:26.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

(7 inline comments)

Overall, you need to follow the structure of the existing exercise scripts; admittedly we changed that a bit in the last few days to make debugging failures a bit easier.  See swift.sh for an example of the banners and error detection we added.

Also, the exercise scripts should only use the client binaries to interact with OpenStack as demonstrating their use is one of their principal functions.  If certain configuration needs to be present for the test to operate, it should be in stack.sh, or called from stack.sh (see keystone_data.sh for an example of this).

And lastly, the exercise script should clean up after itself if successful."}, {'account_id': 447, 'date': '2012-03-03 20:26:33.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: (2 inline comments)

Thanks for the review Dean!

A couple replies in-line.'}, {'account_id': 681, 'date': '2012-03-07 05:23:35.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 5.'}, {'account_id': 2170, 'date': '2012-03-13 22:06:11.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: (4 inline comments)

Looks great. Thanks for doing this. A few very minor changes.'}, {'account_id': 970, 'date': '2012-03-15 20:06:56.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5: Do not submit

Please read the recently added HACKING.rst file in devstack's root, specifically the Exercises section.  

The primary problem with this script is that it starts multiple VMs and does not clean up after itself.  The mysql database access is also still an issue."}, {'account_id': 681, 'date': '2012-03-16 20:47:24.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 6.'}, {'account_id': 681, 'date': '2012-03-20 06:05:41.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 7.'}, {'account_id': 2170, 'date': '2012-03-20 21:57:31.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

(1 inline comment)

Looks good to me. One minor comment regarding whitespace. Thanks!'}, {'account_id': 704, 'date': '2012-03-20 22:40:51.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

(2 inline comments)

I just added two tiny comments'}, {'account_id': 2170, 'date': '2012-03-21 13:39:26.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7: (1 inline comment)

Added comment about keystone environment variable setting: https://bugs.launchpad.net/keystone/+bug/960977. Check to make sure this is set or keystone user-role-add will fail.'}, {'account_id': 970, 'date': '2012-03-21 16:10:33.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7: (4 inline comments)

'}, {'account_id': 2170, 'date': '2012-03-21 22:41:35.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7: (1 inline comment)

Responding to inline comment.'}, {'account_id': 1269, 'date': '2012-03-22 14:30:38.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

(2 inline comments)

'}, {'account_id': 681, 'date': '2012-03-27 22:06:13.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 8.'}, {'account_id': 2170, 'date': '2012-03-27 22:31:55.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

(3 inline comments)

Looks great. A few minor comments.'}, {'account_id': 1155, 'date': '2012-03-28 17:39:28.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 8: (1 inline comment)

I think this was mentioned before, but generally exercises use rest apis, and should be runnable on a machine outside the cluster.  So we try not to use [x]-manage commands, which require privileged conf files and network access to dbs etc.  Similar rationale applies to direct mysql calls.

As for the existing nova-manage calls, some of this may be possible to do through nova's api:

https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/master/nova/api/openstack/compute/contrib/networks.py#L94

Also, is it possible that you could use networks.show to replace your raw mysql query?"}, {'account_id': 1155, 'date': '2012-03-29 17:55:02.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8:

It looks like there is a some api/cli stuff to figure out both for nova and quantum here, but those are larger Folsom issues.  My recommendation is to wait till essex is cut, and then merge this as-is.  Even if it is not perfect, it is useful in that it brings to light the user-facing issues (for which we should log bugs/blueprints) and will make it easier to collaborate to fix those issues.'}, {'account_id': 1155, 'date': '2012-04-12 03:31:57.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

Bump.  Now that we have cut essex we can merge this.  I filed some related bugs:

https://bugs.launchpad.net/quantum/+bug/979530
https://bugs.launchpad.net/quantum/+bug/979527'}, {'account_id': 970, 'date': '2012-04-12 13:22:45.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8: Looks good to me (core reviewer); Approved

'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-04-12 13:38:26.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8: Fails

Build Failed 
 
https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-integration-tests-devstack-vm/3444/ : FAILURE 
https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-devstack-merge/289/ : SUCCESS'}, {'account_id': 1155, 'date': '2012-04-12 15:39:31.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8: No score

What should the default networking mode be for Folsom?  We could just disable this integration test, but at some point I presume we want quantum to become the default driver?'}, {'account_id': 447, 'date': '2012-04-12 16:17:34.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 8:

Talking with Vish, our target is to have Quantum be the default networking mode in Folsom, but not if we have concerns around stability.  We'll probably make a final call around the start of F-4.  

There's going to be a fair amount of churn in Quantum and the Nova + Quantum integration code in the early F milestones, and I don't want that to cause problems for other people."}, {'account_id': 970, 'date': '2012-04-12 16:46:24.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 8: I would prefer that you didn't submit this; No score

We recently added a facility to skip exercise scripts if a required service is not enabled.  See exercises/swift.sh around line 40 for an example.  This will take this script out of the gating process when quantum is not enabled.

And will automatically add it back when we default to quantum enabled."}, {'account_id': 1155, 'date': '2012-04-13 16:36:39.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 9.'}, {'account_id': 1155, 'date': '2012-04-13 16:37:07.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 9:

Dean, I rebased, and added the skip functionality that you mentioned.'}, {'account_id': 970, 'date': '2012-04-13 16:39:11.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 9: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

Thanks Anthony'}, {'account_id': 970, 'date': '2012-04-15 20:40:43.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 9: Approved

commit_message:
Make required changes to tempest.conf build

* Echo out the tempest.conf for easier debugging
* Make sure IDENTITY_HOST defaults to 127.0.0.1
* Source and ensure openrc is available
* Ensure BUILD_TIMEOUT and BUILD_INTERVAL are set appropriately
* Set COMPUTE_RESIZE_AVAILABLE to False because QEMU does not support

Change-Id: If39c3cc011c1a2207fbcb2922094bd9ff2973746

commit_message:
Allow specific tempest tests to be specified

Adds a DEVSTACK_GATE_TEMPEST_TESTS variable that allows
specific tests to be executed. Defaults to all tempest
tests.

subject: Bug ID :888229   Description: Displying project quotas which are not existed in nova database was handled   Fix : when we create a project,nova will allocate the default quota(resources) for the project.        After deleting any project still it diaplays the default quota values for the deleted project,        Changes were made in default quota method in nova-manage . First search in database wheather the        project existed or not,if it existed then calling default quota method otherwise it shows        project does not Existed.

  Description: Displying project quotas which are not existed in nova database was handled
  Fix : when we create a project,nova will allocate the default quota(resources) for the project.
       After deleting any project still it diaplays the default quota values for the deleted project,
       Changes were made in default quota method in nova-manage . First search in database wheather the

       project does not Existed.

commit_message:
Bug ID :888229
  Description: Displying project quotas which are not existed in nova database was handled
  Fix : when we create a project,nova will allocate the default quota(resources) for the project.
       After deleting any project still it diaplays the default quota values for the deleted project,
       Changes were made in default quota method in nova-manage . First search in database wheather the
       project existed or not,if it existed then calling default quota method otherwise it shows
       project does not Existed.

Change-Id: Iff1eddf21bdd3b8221612e2e00c7acdaf58e1712

commit_message:
Use import_object() from openstack.common.utils.

import_object() in nova.utils and openstack.common.utils were the same.
Drop the one from nova.utils and convert all usage to the one from
openstack.common.

This patch also pulls in a fix to import_object() in openstack-common
that has been proposed here: https://review.openstack.org/6191

Change-Id: I9163bba6612e2db7c35ada8b566539e20f38c080

commit_message:
Use openstack-common utils in nova.rpc.

Add utils as a module copied in from openstack.common.  Use
openstack.common.utils from nova.rpc instead nova.utils.  Pulling in
utils required also pulling in exception.

This is a step toward decoupling nova.rpc from nova so that it can
eventually be moved to openstack.common.

Change-Id: Iecd22fd00e32624adf3442bc131c3421d3a77328

subject: Prevent quota threshold falling below current use
messages:
[{'account_id': 679, 'date': '2012-03-29 15:31:09.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

I'm not sure this really makes sense.  There's more places than this where quotas can be reduced (configured defaults, quota classes), and in those cases, it's not clear to me that we can use similar algorithms.

One potential option could be to include logic in my patch that functioned thusly: when in_use is resynchronized, we make note of any quotas below in_use and add/update a quota on the project such that the headroom would be 0, along with emitting a log message and/or notification that this action was taken.  This would effectively allow grandfathering of existing projects in the event their quota class (or the default quotas) was modified."}, {'account_id': 693, 'date': '2012-03-29 16:30:26.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

This doesn't really look like a bug fix, but a feature request for quotas that requires more discussion than a review will provide. I do not think the base quota system should force grandfathering, it breaks the concept of quotas for enterprise and regulated deployments. This should be an extension to the quota extension or enabled via a flag."}, {'account_id': 2284, 'date': '2012-03-29 18:20:10.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Hi Kevin,

Good point about the quota-classes and default quotas.

So, how large would quota classes be typically? (in terms of the number of tenants encompassed by a single class)

I'm wondering whether it would be feasible on quota update to issue a query to determine the max usage of that resource type for any tenant currently in the quota class, and then use that as the floor for the threshold change.

Of course we'd also need to conisder the current usage of any tenant being added to a quota class, and perhaps reject the addition if any threshold is exceeded by the new tenant.

The case of default quotas is less tractable, as it potentially applies to a very large group of tenants. However, it may be acceptable to provide a weaker guarantee in that case (i.e. that reduction of any default quota threshold is "best effort" and not guaranteed to line up with the current usage of all tenants covered by the default quota).

Cheers,
Eoghan'}, {'account_id': 679, 'date': '2012-03-29 18:42:20.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

> So, how large would quota classes be typically? (in terms
> of the number of tenants encompassed by a single class)

Well, that depends.  The use case I had in mind while adding quota classes was the case of a provider that offers different levels of service based on the particular contract with the customer; so, the entry-level customers—which may the bulk of the customers in terms of numbers—may have one set of quota values, while a larger customer may have a higher level of service and thus a higher set of quotas.  That could be a substantial number of tenants.

> I'm wondering whether it would be feasible on quota
> update to issue a query to determine the max usage of
> that resource type for any tenant currently in the quota
> class, and then use that as the floor for the threshold
> change.

I'm resistant to that concept.  One of the other, future directions I feel quotas needs to go in is the ability to use an external quota manager; this would facilitate enforcing quotas across a large number of cells.  (Of course, you probably wouldn't be issuing quota updates through nova in that case, but…)

> The case of default quotas is less tractable, as it
> potentially applies to a very large group of tenants.
> However, it may be acceptable to provide a weaker
> guarantee in that case (i.e. that reduction of any
> default quota threshold is "best effort" and not
> guaranteed to line up with the current usage of all
> tenants covered by the default quota).

I had also considered simply dispensing with default quotas and adding a default quota class, which could then be tuned appropriately.  However, my own personal take on the quota change question is that it's not really a technical problem, but rather a policy issue.  From the technical side, we can arrange quota checks to ensure that if a tenant is over a quota due to that quota being changed, they could still reduce the in_use number, i.e., delete instances; but from the policy side, I'd expect organizations to reduce quota limits very rarely, and only if they absolutely need to—perhaps in the case of migration from beta to public availability, for instance…or in the case they need to place stricter limits on a misbehaving tenant.'}, {'account_id': 2284, 'date': '2012-04-03 14:27:25.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2012-04-18 06:03:08.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

code review expired after 2 weeks of no activity'}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2012-04-18 06:03:09.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Abandoned

code review expired after 2 weeks of no activity'}]

commit_message:
Prevent quota threshold falling below current use

Fixes bug 968175

The current in use count for a resource now acts as a floor for
quota threshold reduction.

This prevents negative headroom arising from the quota threshold
being reduced to below the current usage level.

Change-Id: I8d11b3022ddfebbcdaae4d87bf8a18a9138120c8

commit_message:
Add identity class to swift_auth

 * Adds a class to encapsulate identity data and serialization of that
   data to and from headers.  The intent is to improve both code and
   test clarity.
 * Updated identity marshalling to read USER_NAME instead of USER and
   include USER_ID.

Change-Id: I2f3d64311a7a5c1ac1f41302a62e29961ccca4c8

subject: Allow replication count to be incremented.
messages:
[{'account_id': 144, 'date': '2012-03-18 06:52:16.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 144, 'date': '2012-03-18 06:59:39.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Here's my attempt at solving this.  The idea is simply to add another "row" to the _replica2part2dev array; it doesn't alter the existing replicas; and it attempts to adopt the same placement strategy as  _initial_balance.  Is this correct in principle?

I should confess that I haven't yet tried actually deploying the changed ring yet - I need to spin up another swift node first.

I've been doing the following to test it out...


rm test.builder

echo "Creating single-node ring"
swift-ring-builder test.builder create 8 1 1

export WEIGHT=100               # relative weight (higher for bigger/faster disks)
export DEVICE=sdb1

export ZONE=1
swift-ring-builder test.builder add z$ZONE-10.0.0.${ZONE}:6002/$DEVICE $WEIGHT

swift-ring-builder test.builder  rebalance

swift-ring-builder test.builder
swift-ring-builder test.builder debug_dump


echo "Adding second node"
export ZONE=2
swift-ring-builder test.builder add z$ZONE-10.0.0.${ZONE}:6002/$DEVICE $WEIGHT

swift-ring-builder test.builder pretend_min_part_hours_passed
swift-ring-builder test.builder  rebalance

swift-ring-builder test.builder
swift-ring-builder test.builder debug_dump

echo "Increasing replication to 2"
swift-ring-builder test.builder increment_replicas

swift-ring-builder test.builder
swift-ring-builder test.builder debug_dump


echo "Adding lots more nodes"

export ZONE=3
swift-ring-builder test.builder add z$ZONE-10.0.0.${ZONE}:6002/$DEVICE $WEIGHT

export ZONE=4
swift-ring-builder test.builder add z$ZONE-10.0.0.${ZONE}:6002/$DEVICE $WEIGHT

export ZONE=5
swift-ring-builder test.builder add z$ZONE-10.0.0.${ZONE}:6002/$DEVICE $WEIGHT

export ZONE=6
swift-ring-builder test.builder add z$ZONE-10.0.0.${ZONE}:6002/$DEVICE $WEIGHT

export ZONE=7
swift-ring-builder test.builder add z$ZONE-10.0.0.${ZONE}:6002/$DEVICE $WEIGHT

export ZONE=8
swift-ring-builder test.builder add z$ZONE-10.0.0.${ZONE}:6002/$DEVICE $WEIGHT

export ZONE=9
swift-ring-builder test.builder add z$ZONE-10.0.0.${ZONE}:6002/$DEVICE $WEIGHT




swift-ring-builder test.builder pretend_min_part_hours_passed
swift-ring-builder test.builder  rebalance

swift-ring-builder test.builder
swift-ring-builder test.builder debug_dump


echo "Increasing replication to 3"
swift-ring-builder test.builder increment_replicas

swift-ring-builder test.builder
swift-ring-builder test.builder debug_dump


echo "A rebalance is a good idea after a replication increment from 2->3"
swift-ring-builder test.builder pretend_min_part_hours_passed
swift-ring-builder test.builder  rebalance

swift-ring-builder test.builder
swift-ring-builder test.builder debug_dump'}, {'account_id': 330, 'date': '2012-04-02 01:00:22.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

bump to prevent falling off the list'}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2012-04-16 06:03:01.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

code review expired after 2 weeks of no activity'}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2012-04-16 06:03:02.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Abandoned

code review expired after 2 weeks of no activity'}]

When deploying swift for real, it would be nice to be able to start with a single node
and then grow.

Change-Id: I156a121db30dfa91e6f04b60b9e07782912e00f2
'}, {'created': '2012-03-18 06:52:16.000000000', 'message': 'Allow replication count to be incremented.

When deploying swift for real, it would be nice to be able to start with a single node
and then grow.

Bug #958144

Change-Id: I156a121db30dfa91e6f04b60b9e07782912e00f2
'}]
commit_message:
Allow replication count to be incremented.

When deploying swift for real, it would be nice to be able to start with a single node
and then grow.

Bug #958144

Change-Id: I156a121db30dfa91e6f04b60b9e07782912e00f2

(5 inline comments)

I wonder if it makes sense to merge these two files into a manage-vdi.sh (they share plenty of code) and reference functions rather than files in build_xva.sh. 

Other comments inline."}, {'account_id': 2535, 'date': '2012-04-09 18:55:00.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 2535, 'date': '2012-04-10 00:19:02.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 2535, 'date': '2012-04-11 19:31:01.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 2535, 'date': '2012-04-11 23:17:27.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4:

Hi Armando,

To address your manage-vdi comment, I don't mind creating a single script. I like the flexibility of being able to call these from command line though... they are generic operations after all. It was pretty useful to have when I was tweaking the domU files in dom0."}, {'account_id': 1155, 'date': '2012-04-11 23:20:31.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

Looks good, pending Armando's +1"}, {'account_id': 748, 'date': '2012-04-11 23:58:36.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

you can still do, if you had something like:

manage-vdi [open|close] vm device part

Then, you can just use the file to import functions if $# is zero.

How does that sound?'}, {'account_id': 2535, 'date': '2012-04-12 02:18:22.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 5.'}, {'account_id': 2535, 'date': '2012-04-12 02:19:56.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

Done. The script is now used as: manage-vdi [open|close] vm device partition'}, {'account_id': 748, 'date': '2012-04-12 21:58:22.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

(1 inline comment)

Not sure it works if you are in a XenServer pool, but then neither does nova, you need to start with stand-a-lone machines. commit_message:
XenServer new install: modify README

Modify the README to specify the new steps to install Openstack on
XenServer. Specifically, the new install will use a network-installed
Ubuntu VM on the XenServer host and install the OpenStack services on it.
This eliminates the need for the dev machine (which was required
with XenServer 6.0 and above).

Change-Id: I5f86aa7929754e04ec4a959053c3fb871e3cda76

commit_message:
Refactors kernel and ramdisk handling into their own method.

The size of `_create_instance` is making it increasingly difficult to
work with. This is part of a series of patches aims to break it up into
smaller, more digestible pieces.

Change-Id: Ic668f0414937b255b1b1e1392c204307665822aa

Full instance objects are passed to all methods now, so it no longer

commit_message:
Simplify _get_vm_opaque_ref in xenapi driver

Full instance objects are passed to all methods now, so it no longer
needs to handle three different variants of argument. Also, make sure
most code uses _get_vm_opaque_ref instead of calling VMHelper.lookup
directly so it checks that a vm_ref was actually returned.

Change-Id: Icc8b819e1d4b8bf342867d09e61fe05e6eab9e70

commit_message:
Merge _spawn and _configure_instance in xenapi driver

They were separated only to make it easier to stubout, but we want
more test coverage, not less. So merge them together and fix the
tests while we're at it.

Change-Id: I18333017868b91fb71b8d3dce831463a1cd5bf81

commit_message:
Test unrescue works as well

The only unrescue test that happens right now is that it fails if not
already in rescue. This test fills out to test unrescue works as
intended. Also, remove unnecessary stub from rescue test.

Change-Id: I4451afe5a7d2ada8dfaefad804345b66ac895094

subject: Prevent task-state changing operations during resize.
reviewers: [{'_account_id': 100, 'name': 'Johannes Erdfelt', 'email': 'johannes@erdfelt.com', 'username': 'johannes.erdfelt'}, {'_account_id': 475, 'name': 'Rick Harris', 'email': 'rick.harris@rackspace.com', 'username': 'rconradharris'}, {'_account_id': 616, 'name': 'Mark Washenberger', 'email': 'mark.washenberger@markwash.net', 'username': 'markwash'}, {'_account_id': 679, 'name': 'Kevin L. Mitchell', 'email': 'klmitch@mit.edu', 'username': 'klmitch'}, {'_account_id': 1030, 'name': 'Chris Behrens', 'email': 'cbehrens@codestud.com', 'username': 'cbehrens'}, {'_account_id': 2166, 'name': 'SmokeStack CI', 'username': 'smokestack', 'tags': ['SERVICE_USER']}]
messages:
[{'account_id': 100, 'date': '2012-04-09 22:36:58.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: (1 inline comment)

I like the patch in general, but what are your thoughts on allowing delete during RESIZE_VERIFY?'}, {'account_id': 475, 'date': '2012-04-09 22:45:48.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

I could go either way on it.

If I *had* to pick, I'd lean against it, but that's just because I favor a more rigid state diagram in general.

That said,  it does make it a little more difficult on the user, and in the case of a delete at least, we really can do the right thing, so it's not terrible to allow it."}, {'account_id': 616, 'date': '2012-04-10 16:14:46.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

Accepting this bug is better than restricting deletes.

The only way we're really going to fix these types of issues is by putting sensible state management (and in my view serialization of actions per instance) down in the compute manager, not at the api level."}, {'account_id': 1030, 'date': '2012-04-10 16:56:05.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

I think this quick fix is fine in general, but I'd like to see the delete behavior restored as we can definitely handle that case."}, {'account_id': 616, 'date': '2012-04-10 19:02:15.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

There is a background cleanup process that takes care of original instances, right? Could that cleanup process be based on outstanding migrations rather than instance states?

This change appears to exchange potential operator frustration with potential user frustration, which makes no sense to me.'}, {'account_id': 475, 'date': '2012-04-10 19:35:22.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

> There is a background cleanup process that takes care of original instances, right? Could that cleanup process be based on outstanding migrations rather than instance states?

I see a task for auto-confirming migrations after a period of time, but off-hand, don't see a task for sweeping orphaned instances. (running-deleted-instances is slightly different, though perhaps it could be extended to handle this case as well).

> This change appears to exchange potential operator frustration with potential user frustration, which makes no sense to me.

My feeling is, for everyone sanity--operators who want an orderly flow of tasks that don't race with each other, and user who want consistent, reliable behavior--we should have a more rigid state diagram. This means restricting much more what the user can do at any given time.

Our current approach is to be as loose in this regard as possible. This gives a superficial feeling of "ease" for the user, but sacrifices this consistency and reliability requirement, and if we continue, we'll likely find ourselves buried under a mountain of inscrutable edge-case handling code.

The alternative, is to set expectations with the user that one "operation" is permitted at a time (no deleting a migrated instance... confirm then delete it, for example), and move to a more explicit, well-documented state-machine. The end result, I think, would be far more maintainable, and ultimately, I think would make *more* sense to users.'}, {'account_id': 679, 'date': '2012-04-10 19:42:40.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

As someone who recently experienced this, I have to say it was a bit frustrating to not be able to delete my instance, because I couldn't figure out how to confirm the migration.  Now, granted, this was a UI problem—the option was present, but not immediately visible—but still…"}, {'account_id': 616, 'date': '2012-04-12 02:25:41.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

> The alternative, is to set expectations with
> the user that one "operation" is permitted at
> a time (no deleting a migrated instance...
> confirm then delete it, for example), and
> move to a more explicit, well-documented
> state-machine.

Adding to automated janitorial work is another immediate alternative.

> Our current approach is to be as loose in this regard as possible. This gives a superficial feeling of "ease" for the user, but sacrifices this consistency and reliability requirement, and if we continue, we'll likely find ourselves buried under a mountain of inscrutable edge-case handling code.

I share your feeling about the current approach. I would just like to explore tightening up the state machine on the back end--*cough*--because that could maintain the feeling of ease for users, at least in general. But I understand that adding state management to the manager level is going to be a much larger undertaking. (Also I would cut through the edge-cases by just serializing the manager work per instance, but I suppose that is really part of a different discussion.)'}, {'account_id': 475, 'date': '2012-04-13 23:10:41.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Abandoning this for now. Hopefully we can get some good discussions going on this topic at the Folsom summit :)'}, {'account_id': 475, 'date': '2012-04-13 23:11:05.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Abandoned

Let's discuss this at the Folsom summit!"}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2012-04-09 22:31:04.000000000', 'message': 'Prevent task-state changing operations during resize.

Fixes bug 965630

Any action that changes task-state will overwrite the resize-verify
task-state potentially causing leaking the original resized instance.

Change-Id: Ibb7a5f1ca37231b8737c2cab417c6b1fb2d5cb3d
'}]
commit_message:
Prevent task-state changing operations during resize.

Fixes bug 965630

Any action that changes task-state will overwrite the resize-verify
task-state potentially causing leaking the original resized instance.

Change-Id: Ibb7a5f1ca37231b8737c2cab417c6b1fb2d5cb3d

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-04-05 21:32:59.000000000', 'message': 'Makes the ldap backend return the same role metadata on auth as other backends

The LDAP backend was not returning { "roles": [ "role", "otherrole" ] } for user metadata on authentication, causing dash and command-line tools to be unhappy.

Change-Id: Iccaea019ef1a0df708dc3a2cecc337b21cf382fc
'}, {'created': '2012-04-11 16:41:51.000000000', 'message': 'Makes the ldap backend return proper role metadata

The LDAP backend was not returning { "roles": [ "role", "otherrole" ]
} for user metadata on authentication, causing dash and command-line
tools to be unhappy.

Change-Id: Iccaea019ef1a0df708dc3a2cecc337b21cf382fc
'}, {'created': '2012-04-11 16:53:50.000000000', 'message': 'Makes the ldap backend return proper role metadata

The LDAP backend was not returning { "roles": [ "role", "otherrole" ]
} for user metadata on authentication, causing dash and command-line
tools to be unhappy.

Change-Id: Iccaea019ef1a0df708dc3a2cecc337b21cf382fc
'}, {'created': '2012-04-13 21:20:31.000000000', 'message': 'Makes the ldap backend return proper role metadata

The LDAP backend was not returning role metadata in the form of:

{ "roles": [ "<role_id>", "<role_id>" ] }

for user metadata on authentication, causing dash and command-line
tools to be unhappy.

Change-Id: Iccaea019ef1a0df708dc3a2cecc337b21cf382fc
'}]
commit_message:
Makes the ldap backend return proper role metadata

The LDAP backend was not returning role metadata in the form of:

{ "roles": [ "<role_id>", "<role_id>" ] }

for user metadata on authentication, causing dash and command-line
tools to be unhappy.

Change-Id: Iccaea019ef1a0df708dc3a2cecc337b21cf382fc

commit_message:
Script for Ubuntu 11.10 on Xenserver

This script creates a template for an Ubuntu 11.10 VM on Xenserver.
This is not officially supported by Citrix, but is useful, as most
of the Openstack development and instructions are based on it.

Change-Id: I8457f88ebe1065429d4c03de11d7ab0ef22f357a

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-04-12 19:53:27.000000000', 'message': "Don't pass None for any values in post body.

There is unspecifiedness and nonuniformity of the behavior of passing
None values to create server. So don't do it.
The case of the 'meta' keyword argument is ugly and it should be changed
to 'metadata' but the various APIs are inconsistent about this so I didn't
want to mess with that now and risk breaking something.

Change-Id: I3a8a3afbc179a54b524db0e2ed04d1542401f4a7
"}]
commit_message:
Don't pass None for any values in post body.

There is unspecifiedness and nonuniformity of the behavior of passing
None values to create server. So don't do it.
The case of the 'meta' keyword argument is ugly and it should be changed
to 'metadata' but the various APIs are inconsistent about this so I didn't
want to mess with that now and risk breaking something.

Change-Id: I3a8a3afbc179a54b524db0e2ed04d1542401f4a7

commit_message:
Make exposed methods clearer in xenapi.vmops

VMOps is only used by connection.py, but it's not always obvious
which methods are intended to be public and which are used
internally for implementation reasons. Prefix any internal methods
with _ to make that clearer.

Change-Id: I50244c18233d6d7463057cf5df42d5a5a3a6fab9

[{'created': '2012-04-12 16:48:24.000000000', 'message': 'Ensure swift auth URL includes trailing slash

Fixes bug 979745

Image objects in swift were previously leaked post-deletion

'}]
commit_message:
Ensure swift auth URL includes trailing slash

Fixes bug 979745

Image objects in swift were previously leaked post-deletion
due to a silent auth failure caused by the absense of the
trailing forward slash on the swift connection auth URL.

Change-Id: I9c73a2f75a6466e73801ababdd81db77701ccb20

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-04-10 22:13:17.000000000', 'message': 'Fix errors in os-networks extension

 * Makes sure the uuid is returned as id if it exists
 * Simplifies db get for manager.get_networks
 * Removes direct db access from manager which was breaking test
 * Updates tests to verify the new logic
 * Makes sure Remote NotFounds are turned into 404s
   (The RemoteError blocks can be removed once
    https://review.openstack.org/5749 lands)
 * Fixes bug 977712
 * Fixes bug 977723

Change-Id: I6aa815960782c7ae5165aeebd83bdaaa62c19b04
'}]
commit_message:
Fix errors in os-networks extension

 * Makes sure the uuid is returned as id if it exists
 * Simplifies db get for manager.get_networks
 * Removes direct db access from manager which was breaking test
 * Updates tests to verify the new logic
 * Makes sure Remote NotFounds are turned into 404s
   (The RemoteError blocks can be removed once
    https://review.openstack.org/5749 lands)
 * Fixes bug 977712
 * Fixes bug 977723

Change-Id: I6aa815960782c7ae5165aeebd83bdaaa62c19b04

Maybe I'm missing something here :)  

Does this fix the problem described in the bug itself, or does it introduce a new function that would be used in a future commit?  

Also, I think the best approach to dealing with the issue of plugins.ini is to eliminate it all together and put the configuration in quantum.conf, as described in https://bugs.launchpad.net/quantum/+bug/803086

Does that fix your concern as well?"}, {'account_id': 2350, 'date': '2012-04-13 06:03:03.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Not sure about it. Some time ago it was mentioned on the ML. A new e-mail on the ML would be nice. :)'}, {'account_id': 2350, 'date': '2012-04-13 06:03:03.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

The code looks good and solves the bug as proposed. No tests for it?'}, {'account_id': 2350, 'date': '2012-04-13 06:03:03.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

You're right, no tests for common library yet. The patch is good, we need to write tests for the common library but it should be done on another patch."}, {'account_id': 2874, 'date': '2012-04-13 06:03:03.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

I cannot see test framework in quantumclient project like other projects. 

Of course, I have run and debug it in my Dev env.'}, {'account_id': 2874, 'date': '2012-04-13 06:03:03.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Where are our approver(s)? I was blocked by this commit before I can fix a bug of Quantuam --config-file and a bug of Devstack.'}, {'account_id': 2874, 'date': '2012-04-13 06:03:03.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Regarding "no tests for common library yet"
Is there anyone working on it? If not, I will file a bug for it: such as tests for common library is needed for quantumclient. And I will work on it.'}, {'account_id': 2874, 'date': '2012-04-13 06:03:03.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

that bug described in https://bugs.launchpad.net/quantum/+bug/803086 was reported by Somik Behera on 2011-06-28 and Salvatore Orlando has been working on it since 2011-10-13. It seems there is no much progress yet. Moreover, I think quantum.conf should be able to integrate plugins.ini and specify where the plugin provider's configuration file too. This way, quantum-server --config_file=quantum.conf can weave all the configurations together. 
In fact, 
class QuantumManager(object):

    _instance = None

    def __init__(self, options=None, config_file=None):
        # If no options have been provided, create an empty dict
        if not options:
            options = {}

        fix_path = lambda p: os.path.abspath(os.path.expanduser(p))
        if config_file:
            config_file = fix_path(config_file)
            config_file = [config_file]

        self.configuration_file = find_config_file(options, config_file,
                                                   CONFIG_FILE)
        LOG.debug("Using plugins_ini %s", self.configuration_file)
        if not 'plugin_provider' in options:
            options['plugin_provider'] = \
                utils.get_plugin_from_config(self.configuration_file)
        LOG.debug("Plugin location:%s", options['plugin_provider'])

Just as shown by above codes, value for plugin_provider can be specified in options instead of reading it frm plugins.ini. With the same way, we can get provider's ini file location from options too. 
The options should be content defined in quantum.conf after integration with command line options.

This commit is just for compatible way to deal with independent plugins.ini file. So if options do not contain provider's ini file location, we can get it from the plugins.ini file. also plugins.ini should be able to specified in quantum.conf if any.

summary: 
quantum-server --config_file=quantum.conf.

way 1: 
quantum.conf:
   plugins_ini = path/to/plugins.ini

plugins.ini:
provider = quantum.plugins.openvswitch.ovs_quantum_plugin.OVSQuantumPlugin
provider_ini = /etc/quantum/ovs_quantum_plugin.ini
or way 2:
quantum.conf:
plugin_provider = quantum.plugins.openvswitch.ovs_quantum_plugin.OVSQuantumPlugin
provider_ini = /etc/quantum/ovs_quantum_plugin.ini

my current commit is part of way 1, which is compatible with current status quo. I am adding one general method to read item from plugins.ini. 

my fix to next bug is to implement way 1. my code is ready for it. If this commit can go, I will submit my next commit.

Afte way 1, way 2 is easy to implement. I will do it for one day.

Thanks'}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2012-04-13 06:03:03.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Abandoned

code review expired after 2 weeks of no activity'}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2012-04-13 06:03:03.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

code review expired after 2 weeks of no activity'}]

'}]

commit_message:
Bumping Horizon Django dependency to v1.4 for Folsom.

Horizon is moving to Django 1.4 as the minimum version, however
1.4 is not the packaged version in the apt repositories. Thereby
the dependency needs to be moved back to being installed by pip.

Change-Id: I3c3116c1d02bdfaccab521175816502fd8ea054a

commit_message:
Fix undefined glance_host in get_glance_client

get_glance_client is stubbed in the tests, so they didn't catch it.
Added tests to catch it.

This is related to bug 883328.

Also, add myself to Authors file.

[Backported from
7a5b8822791dc9af0afe7166af34c6fb5277f81c and
c7532c62ea6afb4bfcf3d00e42a58cc72b12405b]

Change-Id: Idbe6c06c22ca1a50df589e016ea5e5924b0cc29d

commit_message:
Use options.os_auth_url rather then environment variable

If you do specify --os_auth_url rather than using the environment variable
OS_AUTH_URL, you'll end up with different behaviour.

Change-Id: I7430c2a619487375427b1c377ce00245eff107ff

commit_message:
API v2 controller/serialization separation

* images and access are now separated into deserializers, controllers, and serializers
* now using schemas to valide incoming requests
* adding create methods for image access
* removing ImageNotFound as it was only being generated by fakes, using NotFound until the backend is updated

Change-Id: Ida3c1b117ee0147e818b74518e84ef9101cbdfc3

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-04-11 22:15:43.000000000', 'message': 'Use project_id in ec2.cloud._format_image()

The previous change (2f8250ce2b) reverted an earlier change verbatim
that broke image publication using deprecated auth.  As it turns out,
image metadata formatting in EC2 should use project_id with
deprecated_auth, not owner_id as it once was in the past.

Change-Id: I0e3bad0149577e71a97916398f665566b529a696
'}]
commit_message:
Use project_id in ec2.cloud._format_image()

The previous change (2f8250ce2b) reverted an earlier change verbatim
that broke image publication using deprecated auth.  As it turns out,
image metadata formatting in EC2 should use project_id with
deprecated_auth, not owner_id as it once was in the past.

Change-Id: I0e3bad0149577e71a97916398f665566b529a696

subject: 012_id_to_uuid: Also convert ramdisk + kernel ids
messages:
[{'account_id': 1132, 'date': '2012-04-07 22:57:05.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

The mapping you are updating is actually maintained by Nova, so It would make more sense to just provide a migration tool for Diablo -> Essex in the Nova codebase. I'm not really interested in putting this logic in Glance."}, {'account_id': 1420, 'date': '2012-04-09 17:09:08.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

I'm not sure that mapping exists in Nova.  Or, if it does, it's not being used during instance spawn.  Paraphrased from _create_instance() in nova/compute/api.py, these IDs come directly from the registry:

image = image_service.show(context, image_id)
...
kernel_id = image['properties'].get('kernel_id', None)
ramdisk_id = image['properties'].get('ramdisk_id', None)
...
image_service.show(context, kernel_id)
image_service.show(context, ramdisk_id)

.. with the exceptions being raised in on the glance side during image_service.show()"}, {'account_id': 1420, 'date': '2012-04-09 17:10:40.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Paste fail.. http://paste.ubuntu.com/922107/'}, {'account_id': 1132, 'date': '2012-04-09 17:39:39.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

My point is that Glance doesn't know what kernel_id and ramdisk_id are, they're just arbitrary properties. A user can set them to anything and Glance wouldn't care. When I say 'maintained by Nova', I mean that Nova is responsible for how the mapping is created and used."}, {'account_id': 67, 'date': '2012-04-09 19:03:47.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Brian: I agree that nova should be responsible for driving this, but nova has no way of finding out the old id of the images so I don't know how it could.  Perhaps we could expose an administrative method that nova could call to convert them?  Seems like in this case it is way easier to cheat and let glance do it."}, {'account_id': 1132, 'date': '2012-04-11 05:34:49.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Ok, I don't think I see a reasonable alternative to your proposal. However, would it make sense to limit the db update to kernel_id and ramdisk_id rather than any values that matches an arbitrary integer? I'm thinking we could end up overwriting someones data unintentionally."}, {'account_id': 67, 'date': '2012-04-11 20:47:17.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

Waldon: good point. I actually thing that limiting this to look specifically for kernel_id and ramdisk_id might be best."}, {'account_id': 1420, 'date': '2012-04-11 21:59:08.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 7, 'date': '2012-04-12 00:04:25.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

lgtm. thx Adam.'}, {'account_id': 1132, 'date': '2012-04-12 15:27:23.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Looks good to me (core reviewer); Approved

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-04-07 19:04:45.000000000', 'message': '012_id_to_uuid: Also convert ramdisk + kernel ids

The original migration converts numerical IDs to UUIDs.  It updates
image_members and image_properties that reference image_id, but stops
short of updating actual properties that reference the new UUIDs,
specifically kernel_ids and ramdisk_ids.  This breaks launching
of instances in Nova whos images are associated with a kernel and/or rd.

Also, this fixes an issue when migrating against non-sqlite
databases where the actual conversion is executed twice.

Fixes bug 975655
Fixes bug 975651

Change-Id: I76ecabc5ee266e2e9765740721e8ec1722cc5a7c
'}, {'created': '2012-04-11 21:59:08.000000000', 'message': '012_id_to_uuid: Also convert ramdisk + kernel ids

The original migration converts numerical IDs to UUIDs.  It updates
image_members and image_properties that reference image_id, but stops
short of updating actual properties that reference the new UUIDs,
specifically kernel_ids and ramdisk_ids.  This breaks launching
of instances in Nova whos images are associated with a kernel and/or rd.

Also, this fixes an issue when migrating against non-sqlite
databases where the actual conversion is executed twice.

Fixes bug 975655
Fixes bug 975651

Update: Only update kernel_ids and ramdisk_ids in image_properties

Change-Id: I76ecabc5ee266e2e9765740721e8ec1722cc5a7c
'}]
commit_message:
012_id_to_uuid: Also convert ramdisk + kernel ids

The original migration converts numerical IDs to UUIDs.  It updates
image_members and image_properties that reference image_id, but stops
short of updating actual properties that reference the new UUIDs,
specifically kernel_ids and ramdisk_ids.  This breaks launching
of instances in Nova whos images are associated with a kernel and/or rd.

Also, this fixes an issue when migrating against non-sqlite
databases where the actual conversion is executed twice.

Fixes bug 975655
Fixes bug 975651

Update: Only update kernel_ids and ramdisk_ids in image_properties
        when converting to UUIDs

Change-Id: I76ecabc5ee266e2e9765740721e8ec1722cc5a7c

subject: Adds basic tests for disk config extension
messages:
[{'account_id': 1192, 'date': '2012-03-28 15:28:45.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

This looks OK to me except for one thing. Is it correct to "wait" for RESIZE and then for ACTIVE? Isn't it possible that when wait_for_server_status is called first, the state is not yet in VERIFY_RESIZE, but during the build_time sleep it has gone to VERIFY_RESIZE and then to ACTIVE? Then the first call would hang. I had been thinking about this with regard to fixing the reboot tests which have the same issue. 

Or is there some guarantee that a state change happens before the API call returns?'}, {'account_id': 97, 'date': '2012-03-28 15:36:16.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

I don't follow David. I wait for VERIFY_RESIZE, not RESIZE. Yes, if I did wait for a transient state, it would be possible to miss a state change and get stuck (which is why I'm not doing that). VERIFY_RESIZE is a stable state, and will not change until further action is taken."}, {'account_id': 1192, 'date': '2012-03-28 15:41:52.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Indeed. I hadn't read that part of the resize doc carefully enough. Sorry about that."}, {'account_id': 7, 'date': '2012-03-30 19:59:41.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

These look great, thanks Daryl!'}, {'account_id': 97, 'date': '2012-04-12 15:53:11.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:
