subject: Kill glance-api child workers on SIGINT
messages:
[{'account_id': 679, 'date': '2012-04-11 17:18:46.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: (1 inline comment)

'}, {'account_id': 2284, 'date': '2012-04-11 17:22:55.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: (1 inline comment)

Thanks for the review Kevin, response inline.

Cheers,
Eoghan'}, {'account_id': 7, 'date': '2012-04-11 17:27:45.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Seems sensible -- though I think removing the sys.exit() call in the Server is necessary too.

Eoghan, I hate to be annoying, but is there a way we can test this fix? I know it's not the easiest thing to test... but you did a bang-up job with the glance-control testing :)

-jay"}, {'account_id': 679, 'date': '2012-04-11 17:28:35.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: (1 inline comment)

'}, {'account_id': 2284, 'date': '2012-04-11 20:29:37.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 2284, 'date': '2012-04-11 20:39:08.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Thanks for the review Jay.

Test added in patch set 2 which fires SIGINT at all the glance-api processes (as would the terminal driver on ctrl+c) and then ensures that no new children are spawned.

Without the fix to wsgi.py, this test shows the storm of respawned children as reported in the bug.

Cheers,
Eoghan'}, {'account_id': 2284, 'date': '2012-04-11 20:43:01.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 2284, 'date': '2012-04-11 20:44:37.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

Thanks for the further comment Kevin, response inline.

Cheers,
Eoghan'}, {'account_id': 679, 'date': '2012-04-11 22:16:25.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: (1 inline comment)

'}, {'account_id': 7, 'date': '2012-04-12 00:02:42.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

Verified the test does show a failure on master and no failure with this patch to wsgi.py. Nice work, Eoghan.'}, {'account_id': 2759, 'date': '2012-04-12 02:34:52.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

I agree with Jay that sys.exit() should be removed.  Other than that, looks good to me.'}, {'account_id': 2284, 'date': '2012-04-12 11:54:46.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 2284, 'date': '2012-04-12 12:00:17.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 5.'}, {'account_id': 2284, 'date': '2012-04-12 12:04:56.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5:

Agreed that the sys.exit() prior to a break is clearly out of place, however it wasn't germane to the current issue, so originally I was minded to leave it in place pending a further patch to remove. However in retrospect, its probably best just to be rid of it, which I've done in the latest patch set.

I've also changed the child signal handling logic slightly, now ignoring interrupts to avoid a race condition whereby a child worker receives the SIGINT before the parent and is respawned unneccessarily as a result.

The downside is that a SIGINT sent to a child only (i.e. not to the parent also) will have no effect. However, I don't think this is a realistic use-case, as selectively killing children is likely to acheived via kill -TERM.

Also re-ordered imports as requested."}, {'account_id': 7, 'date': '2012-04-12 14:24:32.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

Nice work, Eoghan!'}, {'account_id': 679, 'date': '2012-04-12 14:40:36.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: (1 inline comment)

'}, {'account_id': 7, 'date': '2012-04-12 14:41:32.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5:

Kevin, not really... it's just a test anyway, so not really concerned..."}, {'account_id': 679, 'date': '2012-04-12 15:04:45.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

Yeah, I figured, but thought I'd double-check :)  OK, then…"}, {'account_id': 679, 'date': '2012-04-12 15:04:53.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Approved

'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-04-12 15:16:45.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Verified

https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-glance-python27/249/ : SUCCESS'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-04-12 15:16:46.000000000', 'content': 'Change has been successfully merged into the git repository.'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2012-04-11 17:00:52.000000000', 'message': 'Kill glance-api child workers on SIGINT

Fixes bug 978130

Previously glance-api configured to run multiple child
workers went in a respawn tail-spin when the parent is
interrupted with crtl+c.

This is now avoided by terminating the process group when
SIGINT is received, in the same way as SIGTERM is handled.

Change-Id: Ieca90f45e07cc3645a997bba493e0b9a9f08a470
'}, {'created': '2012-04-11 20:29:37.000000000', 'message': 'Kill glance-api child workers on SIGINT

Fixes bug 978130

Previously glance-api configured to run multiple child
workers went in a respawn tail-spin when the parent is
interrupted with crtl+c.

This is now avoided by terminating the process group when
SIGINT is received, in the same way as SIGTERM is handled.

Change-Id: Ieca90f45e07cc3645a997bba493e0b9a9f08a470
'}, {'created': '2012-04-11 20:43:01.000000000', 'message': 'Kill glance-api child workers on SIGINT

commit_message:
Kill glance-api child workers on SIGINT

Fixes bug 978130

Previously glance-api configured to run multiple child
workers went in a respawn tail-spin when the parent is
interrupted with crtl+c.

This is now avoided by terminating the process group when
SIGINT is received, in the same way as SIGTERM is handled.

Change-Id: Ieca90f45e07cc3645a997bba493e0b9a9f08a470

commit_message:
Ensure swift auth URL includes trailing slash

Fixes bug 979745

Image objects in swift were previously leaked post-deletion
due to a silent auth failure caused by the absense of the
trailing forward slash on the swift connection auth URL.

Change-Id: I9c73a2f75a6466e73801ababdd81db77701ccb20

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-04-10 16:45:03.000000000', 'message': 'Fix colorization of "hash" in SAIO doc.

Admittedly, this is ridiculously trivial, but the coloring of
"hash" always peeved me. Not so much that it existed, but that
I did not understand what caused it. After consulting our Sphinx
experts, it turned out that the code block was considered code
in Python and "hash" is a reserved word in Python, so it was
colored.

One option is to declare the code block "ini", which is what
it is, but that causes the block stand out just as badly, unless
we highlight every one of them. So, for now use "none".

Change-Id: Icee021fc30839eeb02cd3e232ff6be92ed32df52
'}]
commit_message:
Fix colorization of "hash" in SAIO doc.

Admittedly, this is ridiculously trivial, but the coloring of
"hash" always peeved me. Not so much that it existed, but that
I did not understand what caused it. After consulting our Sphinx
experts, it turned out that the code block was considered code
in Python and "hash" is a reserved word in Python, so it was
colored.

One option is to declare the code block "ini", which is what
it is, but that causes the block stand out just as badly, unless
we highlight every one of them. So, for now use "none".

Change-Id: Icee021fc30839eeb02cd3e232ff6be92ed32df52

subject: Empty body of POST message issues
messages:
[{'account_id': 1132, 'date': '2012-04-12 06:03:03.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: (1 inline comment)

I'm not sure I buy this approach. I do agree its odd to not return a body for requests that expect it, but I'm not sure we can selectively change the behavior based on action name. We can't dictate how actions map to controller methods, as anything can technically be used. The biggest problem I see is the lack of a convention for PUT to a container resource (which we are using 'update_all' to denote for now). 

When I wrote this code originally, I couldn't come up with a better approach. The current method allows any method to denote whether it requires a body or not, maybe we just need better error handling?"}, {'account_id': 1247, 'date': '2012-04-12 06:03:03.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

Ok, I think we need a few things to make progress here:

  1) Some general discussion with the API maintainers of 
     other projects to confirm that we want to support 
     these semantics for empty POST bodies (or no
     Content-Type)

     I've added bcwaldon to see if he has an opinion, but I
     think you'd be better off discussing on list

  2) Preferably a similar patch for Nova accepted to confirm
     that it's a sane approach for OpenStack APIs

  3) A unit test for this in openstack-common"}, {'account_id': 1247, 'date': '2012-04-12 06:03:03.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Craig - apologies, but it's taking me a while to dig through this stuff to see if your approach makes sense

Could you update the patch with test cases to demonstrate the problem? Thanks

Also, a note in the commit message that this is causing problems for reddwarf would be good"}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2012-04-12 06:03:03.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

code review expired after 1 week of no activity after a negative review'}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2012-04-12 06:03:03.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Abandoned

code review expired after 1 week of no activity after a negative review'}]

subject: Add a --byname argument to the most important calls
messages:
[{'account_id': 144, 'date': '2012-03-16 06:36:20.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 144, 'date': '2012-03-16 07:05:42.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 4, 'date': '2012-03-27 19:59:04.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

I certainly agree that this aspect of the CLI needs some love, but I'm not a fan of this approach. That said, I don't know what the best solution is. I've been thinking one or both of:

A) Deprecate --user, --role, etc in favor of --user_id, --user_name, --role_id, --role_name, etc

B) Add a --id_only option to *-create commands, which avoid displaying the entire response in favor of only displaying the ID attribute and a line break, which would be much easier to parse."}, {'account_id': 144, 'date': '2012-03-27 22:37:18.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

I'm not a big fan of option B.  It still requires scripting.

Option A is fine with me, but it breaks backwards compatibility, doesn't it?

I'd really like to see this make it for Essex, so the documentation can have fewer IDs in it.  It looks like this is the one step that everyone that installs Essex will have to do, so we should make it not be painful.  If we keep the current CLI, I am sure each distro will write their own wrapper script, which will be worse than anything we're contemplating here :-)

I think this is our best bet; it's just one flag and not a huge code change (it could be smaller but then we'd trade intuitiveness for size).  The flag should probably default to true but then we would break everyone's scripts.  We could use 'smart resolution' which would check for both an id and a name, but I thought the (theoretical) indeterminism would be worse."}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2012-04-04 06:03:05.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Abandoned

code review expired after 1 week of no activity after a negative review'}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2012-04-04 06:03:05.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

code review expired after 1 week of no activity after a negative review'}, {'account_id': 144, 'date': '2012-04-04 08:24:41.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: Restored

I think if you vote -1 for this, you should be obliged to write scripts to make it easy instead.  Or just answer all the support requests on this topic for the lifetime of Essex - shouldn't be more than 5 years :-)"}, {'account_id': 4, 'date': '2012-04-04 16:46:32.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

justinb: You might be interested in how devstack handles this with get_id https://github.com/openstack-dev/devstack/blob/master/files/keystone_data.sh'}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2012-04-12 06:03:03.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Abandoned

This allows ec2 image publishing to function on Essex for users
who are still using deprecated auth.  This isn't targetted toward
master and is proposed to stable/essex for the sake of aiding
users transition to Keystone during upgrades from diablo +
deprecated_auth.

Fixes bug 977765

Change-Id: I809b669e88fe25234569d0c744d14aff6bbd4713
"}]
commit_message:
Populate image properties with project_id again

This allows ec2 image publishing to function on Essex for users
who are still using deprecated auth.  This isn't targetted toward
master and is proposed to stable/essex for the sake of aiding
users transition to Keystone during upgrades from diablo +
deprecated_auth.

Fixes bug 977765

Change-Id: I809b669e88fe25234569d0c744d14aff6bbd4713

subject: Detailed keystone SQL examples
messages:
[{'account_id': 964, 'date': '2012-04-02 16:45:18.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

(1 inline comment)

The rest of the guide uses SQL backend... that was what I was hoping to do with the section. I disagree with the pointer to Hastexo in the bug. We plan to bring in that guide as a quick start, this install guide should be more hardened choices for backends."}, {'account_id': 321, 'date': '2012-04-02 20:32:33.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Yeah, so, my motivation for this change was somebody telling me "the existing docs didn't work for me and I found these other docs which did work". 

I was so unsure that I even posted to the general mailing, hoping for a response: https://lists.launchpad.net/openstack/msg09434.html. Alas, none yet.

So, I don't have any problems withdrawing this. However, it does seem like using the MySQL database backend for the service catalog templates means a lot more typing upfront to get things initialized.  What's the advantage of using the MySQL backend to store the service endpoints in a production deployment?'}, {'account_id': 964, 'date': '2012-04-02 20:55:04.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

So the main points are reliability, high availability, and redundancy of the data - all those can be set up easily with MySQL, with template files, not so much.'}, {'account_id': 321, 'date': '2012-04-05 21:05:16.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 321, 'date': '2012-04-05 21:05:54.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

I didn't have a chance to add tenant_ids to the URLs that were done in the commit before this, but the worked examples at the bottom should now show has this is done."}, {'account_id': 161, 'date': '2012-04-05 21:32:23.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

Perhaps we should add a link to another doc (or add to this one) explaining the costs/benefits of using a DB vs using a template file, or the different scenarios or something.

Also, to add to Anne's point, it should probably be made clear that in a production setup you really do want to use a DB as a backend. It's more performant, but more importantly it allows you to much more easily scale since you can bring up N number of keystone front ends and they can all point back to the same DB. Not to mention the built in data replication features and documentation surrounding HA/DR/etc of something like mysql."}, {'account_id': 964, 'date': '2012-04-10 13:31:51.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

Looks like there are still >>>>> markers in the source, can you rebase and resubmit? I'm taking care of bug https://bugs.launchpad.net/openstack-manuals/+bug/977831 with another patch, it shouldn't affect your changes."}, {'account_id': 964, 'date': '2012-04-10 14:51:51.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: No score

Hey Lorin, I'll work on this and submit a patch for it."}, {'account_id': 321, 'date': '2012-04-10 14:54:26.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

Anne:

No problem. I'll push up the last thing I did in case you find it useful, and I'll assume you're going to finish it out."}, {'account_id': 321, 'date': '2012-04-10 14:55:16.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 964, 'date': '2012-04-10 14:56:53.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 964, 'date': '2012-04-10 14:57:24.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

Ok, that's better. One more reviewer, please take a look."}, {'account_id': 964, 'date': '2012-04-10 20:11:23.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 5.'}, {'account_id': 964, 'date': '2012-04-10 20:12:25.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

One more fix to the keystone.conf which should fix bug 973477.'}, {'account_id': 964, 'date': '2012-04-11 16:12:47.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 6.'}, {'account_id': 964, 'date': '2012-04-11 20:24:08.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

'}, {'account_id': 964, 'date': '2012-04-11 20:36:15.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 7.'}, {'account_id': 964, 'date': '2012-04-11 20:38:00.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

'}, {'account_id': 161, 'date': '2012-04-11 20:53:50.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

Nice work Lorin!'}, {'account_id': 161, 'date': '2012-04-11 20:54:28.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve; Approved

commit_message:
Detailed keystone SQL examples

 * Fixed the merge problems
 * Fixed localhost reference in keystone.conf
 * Updated keystone.conf with correct example IP address
 * Fix bug 978955 by fixing curl examples and output examples
 * Changed --username to --os_username for the glance commands
 * Rebased against master

Change-Id: I2c1764fad20fc0d29cb67d165bd7539ea3871b24

commit_message:
Set install_requires in setup.py.

Inline shared version of setup.py from openstack-common. This can
be removed once projects switch over to use the shared version.

Updates setup.py so that it sets install_requires and dependency_links.

Fixes issues where pip installing glance doesn't properly install
dependencies.

Fixes LP Bug #975483.

Change-Id: I5a10b311cfde2fda4d4dac341dd866f868b72d0d

commit_message:
Remove python-novaclient dependency from nova.

Nova should not depend on python-novaclient. Remove it.

Note: In order to get unit tests to pass I had to add in
a temporary dependency on httplib2. This is due to the fact
that pip installing glance does not properly setup all
the dependencies. See LP Bug #975483 for details.

Fixes LP Bug #978992.

Change-Id: I50c00139f9dc303223601230fd962abac977cd5e

commit_message:
Bump python-novaclient version to 2.6.0.1.

Bump the python-novaclient version in pip-requires to 2.6.0.1. The
previous python-novaclient version 2.6.0 was broken and thus
Diablo tests were failing.

Also nails the Glance version in pip-requires to 2011.3.1. This
should fix 'No module named iso8601' errors when running
Diablo tests with the latest Diablo trunk builds.

Change-Id: Idc9bcceaff91afa69fbc255bc39a68d854ac1127

commit_message:
Make '--help' argument more useful.

With no other arguments, '--help' now outputs the same as 'help', so
that the list of subcommands are no longer omitted.  Additionally,
'$subcommand --help' now yields the same output as 'help $subcommand'.

Change-Id: Iabd926574e296ad14b622862b9fba038fdede66e

commit_message:
Skip test depending on sqlite3 if unavailable

Fixes bug 973626

Add @depends_on_exe to declare a test dependency on the availability
of an executable.

Skip TestSqlite.test_big_int_mapping if sqlite3 not available on the
local PATH.

Change-Id: I1b7cf0636f79422f9f31f6a88a493791897a53b4

commit_message:
Compile BigInteger to INTEGER for sqlite

Fixes bug 966243

Ensure BigInteger does not map to BIGINT for an auto-created
sqlite registry DB, as this type is not supported by sqlite.

Change-Id: I61f44fbe50ea406d2d593f8f53cab5da3af2222a

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-04-02 11:45:57.000000000', 'message': "Allow specifying the current version in 'glance-manage version_control'

Fixes bug #966242

The version_control command is a bit useless since you can't actually
specify what version to  use and it defaults to version=0.

Allow the user to specify a version:

  $> glance-manage version_control 9 # set the diablo version

and default to the latest version if none is specified.

Also, allow db_sync to be supplied a version for the case where we're
upgrading an unversioned DB.

Finally, re-work the argument handling in glance-manage to more easily
handle optional args.

The tests are extended to test using db_sync for upgrades and to test
placing an existing database under version control.

Change-Id: I231dc710554198bfd1fdcb82c3c3768963f64bd8
"}, {'created': '2012-04-03 11:30:53.000000000', 'message': "Allow specifying the current version in 'glance-manage version_control'

Allow the user to specify a version:

  $> glance-manage version_control 9 # set the diablo version

and default to the latest version if none is specified.

Also, allow db_sync to be supplied a version for the case where we're
upgrading an unversioned DB.

commit_message:
Allow specifying the current version in 'glance-manage version_control'

Fixes bug #966242

The version_control command is a bit useless since you can't actually
specify what version to  use and it defaults to version=0.

Allow the user to specify a version:

  $> glance-manage version_control 9 # set the diablo version

and default to the latest version if none is specified.

Also, allow db_sync to be supplied a version for the case where we're
upgrading an unversioned DB.

Finally, re-work the argument handling in glance-manage to more easily
handle optional args.

The tests are extended to test using db_sync for upgrades and to test
placing an existing database under version control.

Change-Id: I231dc710554198bfd1fdcb82c3c3768963f64bd8

subject: Change behavior in utils.import_object().
messages:
[{'account_id': 385, 'date': '2012-04-11 06:45:47.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

I don't agree with matching nova here. I'd rather we allow passing in args/kwargs to the __init__ of the resolved class if we are to instantiate it for the user."}, {'account_id': 1247, 'date': '2012-04-11 06:45:47.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

Yeah, I think I agree. Nova's behaviour seems a bit random here - import_object() returns a module or an *instance* of a class ... huh?

How about just renaming import_object to import_module and removing the import_class behaviour from it altogether

Then we could add:

  def import_object(import_str, *args, **kwargs):
      cls = import_class(import_str)
      return cls(*args, **kwargs)"}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-04-11 06:45:47.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Fails

commit_message:
Change behavior in utils.import_object().

Fix bug 972859.

Prior to this patch, utils.import_object(foo) and
utils.import_class(foo) would return the same thing if foo was the path
to a class.  This patch changes utils.import_object() to return an
instance of the class, instead, also allowing you to pass in arguments
to the constructor.

This patch also removes the odd behavior of import_object() to be able
to also import a module.  Instead, a new function import_module() has
been added.

Finally, the three import helpers have been moved to a new module,
importutils.

Change-Id: Ia2ea64c965692f8c3a29adec332dd93a83980070

subject: Proposed HACKING guidelines for string encoding.
reviewers: [{'_account_id': 100, 'name': 'Johannes Erdfelt', 'email': 'johannes@erdfelt.com', 'username': 'johannes.erdfelt'}, {'_account_id': 642, 'name': 'Matt Dietz', 'email': 'matthew.dietz@gmail.com', 'username': 'cerberus'}, {'_account_id': 1247, 'name': 'Mark McLoughlin', 'email': 'markmc@redhat.com', 'username': 'markmc'}, {'_account_id': 1998, 'name': 'andrewbogott', 'username': 'andrewbogott', 'inactive': True}, {'_account_id': 2166, 'name': 'SmokeStack CI', 'username': 'smokestack', 'tags': ['SERVICE_USER']}, {'_account_id': 2472, 'name': 'Doug Hellmann', 'email': 'dhellmann@redhat.com', 'username': 'doug-hellmann'}]
messages:
[{'account_id': 1998, 'date': '2012-03-23 21:52:24.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

This change is defended at length here: http://wiki.openstack.org/encoding'}, {'account_id': 100, 'date': '2012-03-23 22:18:26.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

I don't see what the problem is with string literals that are ascii. The examples show that as WRONG and the wiki explains a lot of problems with strings that are encoded in something other than ascii, but never anything that is strictly ascii."}, {'account_id': 1998, 'date': '2012-03-23 22:28:25.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

I'm not clear when it would be appropriate to have a datatype that is incapable of containing non-English text.  Isn't it best to just design the code for international use from the start?

If there are lots of examples of strings that are purely internal to the project and are never localized or subject to user modification then perhaps the guideline is overstated."}, {'account_id': 100, 'date': '2012-03-23 22:37:18.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

There are literally thousands of string literals in the nova source code. My naive grep counts about 45,000.

I have an immediate problem with anything that calls for updating all of those 45,000 string literals to add a u in front. Especially when there doesn't appear to be any value in doing so.

There are other downsides too, like the bloat in memory (4x more memory, which is better in Python 3.3, but we don't support 3.3 yet).

But more importantly, an ASCII encoded string literal has no problems. If you combine it with a unicode type, then it becomes a unicode type with no problems.

>>> a = 'foo'
>>> b = u'\u2022'
>>> a + b
u'foo\u2022'
>>> '%s%s' % (a, b)
u'foo\u2022'
>>> 'foo%s' % b
u'foo\u2022'

I can't find any situations where using an ASCII encoded string literal (and I only mean literals) can cause any of the problems outlined in the wiki page."}, {'account_id': 1998, 'date': '2012-03-24 13:49:54.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Johannes -- I suspect that you're right; the important thing is understand that the toll-free-bridge from string literal to unicode is one-way.  I'm thinking about how to reword the rule to reflect that."}, {'account_id': 100, 'date': '2012-03-24 13:53:55.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

I agree with the rest of the wiki page, especially with never keeping anything encoded in a string. It should be either an ASCII string literal or converted to unicode (even if it was only ASCII) as soon as possible.

I just have practical issues with it when it comes to string literals :)'}, {'account_id': 1998, 'date': '2012-03-26 21:07:30.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 1998, 'date': '2012-03-26 21:07:47.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

Patchset 2 includes some wiggle-room for string literals.  Let me know if you'd prefer a different wording."}, {'account_id': 100, 'date': '2012-03-26 21:24:11.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

I like this better that before, but I think it could be clearer.

However, I think this text could be stronger.

The proposed changes really only calls out string literals which doesn't cover most user input. I think strings from an external source are where the problem and concern is.

Maybe say that strings should be decoded to 'unicode' type as early as possible with the only exception being string literals that are pure ASCII?"}, {'account_id': 2472, 'date': '2012-03-28 18:18:57.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

'}, {'account_id': 642, 'date': '2012-03-29 18:19:59.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

'}, {'account_id': 1247, 'date': '2012-04-03 11:36:59.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

Thanks for trying to codify sensible rules here, but I'm worried about:

  And, yeah, it feels wrong to guess, but guessing is our 
  only option.

Why is guessing the only option? The environment surely tells us what encoding the current locale is using e.g.

  LANG=en_GB.UTF-8

why can't we not support e.g.

  LANG=en_US.iso88591

Without looking too hard, I see Python has:

 $ LANG=en_GB.UTF-8 python -c 'import locale; print locale.getpreferredencoding()'
UTF-8
 $ LANG=en_GB.iso88591 python -c 'import locale; print locale.getpreferredencoding()'
ISO-8859-1"}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2012-04-11 06:03:02.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

code review expired after 1 week of no activity after a negative review'}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2012-04-11 06:03:03.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Abandoned

code review expired after 1 week of no activity after a negative review'}]

Change-Id: I9e0a8259bf0ba18136a6a4a8754afa9240ecc1ad
'}, {'created': '2012-03-26 21:07:30.000000000', 'message': 'Proposed HACKING guidelines for string encoding.

Change-Id: I9e0a8259bf0ba18136a6a4a8754afa9240ecc1ad
'}]

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-03-25 21:15:03.000000000', 'message': "Clean up read_deleted support in host aggregates code

tl;dr - this is a cleaner fix for bug #949038

It seems clear to me that all of the DB APIs should not explicitly pass
read_deleted='no' or read_deleted='yes' to model_query without good
reason.

We want to allow callers to specify read_deleted via the context and
that only works if we don't explicitly pass it to model_query().

If we don't explicitly specify it to model_query(), we use the value
from the context which defaults to 'no'.

Given all that, there is no need to support read_deleted to any of the
DB API calls because they should support specifying the flag via the
context. There should also be no need to pass read_deleted='no' because
that is the default.

Really, the only place there should be any mention of read_deleted is
where we want read_deleted='yes' behaviour e.g.

  - In tests, where we want to check the operational_state of an
    aggregate after it has been deleted

  - Where we want to support undeleting an aggregate or aggreate host

Change-Id: I916a8d189a33d7f30838cccb26531a024066ef96
"}]
commit_message:
Clean up read_deleted support in host aggregates code

tl;dr - this is a cleaner fix for bug #949038

It seems clear to me that all of the DB APIs should not explicitly pass
read_deleted='no' or read_deleted='yes' to model_query without good
reason.

We want to allow callers to specify read_deleted via the context and
that only works if we don't explicitly pass it to model_query().

If we don't explicitly specify it to model_query(), we use the value
from the context which defaults to 'no'.

Given all that, there is no need to support read_deleted to any of the
DB API calls because they should support specifying the flag via the
context. There should also be no need to pass read_deleted='no' because
that is the default.

Really, the only place there should be any mention of read_deleted is
where we want read_deleted='yes' behaviour e.g.

  - In tests, where we want to check the operational_state of an
    aggregate after it has been deleted

  - Where we want to support undeleting an aggregate or aggreate host

Change-Id: I916a8d189a33d7f30838cccb26531a024066ef96

commit_message:
Fix errors in os-networks extension

 * Makes sure the uuid is returned as id if it exists
 * Simplifies db get for manager.get_networks
 * Removes direct db access from manager which was breaking test
 * Updates tests to verify the new logic
 * Makes sure Remote NotFounds are turned into 404s
   (The RemoteError blocks can be removed once
    https://review.openstack.org/5749 lands)
 * Fixes bug 977712
 * Fixes bug 977723

Change-Id: I6aa815960782c7ae5165aeebd83bdaaa62c19b04

subject: fix TypeError with unstarted threads in nova-network
reviewers: [{'_account_id': 3, 'name': 'Jenkins', 'username': 'jenkins'}, {'_account_id': 67, 'name': 'Vish Ishaya', 'email': 'vishvananda@gmail.com', 'username': 'vishvananda'}, {'_account_id': 100, 'name': 'Johannes Erdfelt', 'email': 'johannes@erdfelt.com', 'username': 'johannes.erdfelt'}, {'_account_id': 679, 'name': 'Kevin L. Mitchell', 'email': 'klmitch@mit.edu', 'username': 'klmitch'}, {'_account_id': 2166, 'name': 'SmokeStack CI', 'username': 'smokestack', 'tags': ['SERVICE_USER']}, {'_account_id': 2340, 'name': 'Ionut Artarisi', 'email': 'iartarisi@suse.cz', 'username': 'mapleoin'}]
messages:
[{'account_id': 2340, 'date': '2012-04-02 14:44:01.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 2340, 'date': '2012-04-02 14:51:29.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

The error seems like it was triggered because getattr(t, ident, hash(t)) returns None when a thread has not been started. (hash(t) is only returned if the thread doesn't have the 'ident' attribute)


I updated my commit because I think I figured out what those strange "& 0xffffff" are for. They seem to be changing the given identifiers to a different arbitrary value. 

Can someone explain why this is needed? (I think it would be useful to put this in a comment, as well)'}, {'account_id': 100, 'date': '2012-04-02 15:01:59.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

I'm not sure I understand how a thread cannot be started yet still execute this code?

Also, can you open up a bug and update your commit message to reference it?"}, {'account_id': 2340, 'date': '2012-04-02 15:29:46.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 67, 'date': '2012-04-02 17:41:31.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

The 0xffffffff is taken from the inherited parent lockfile code.  It truncates the thread ident to 32 bits.  Honestly, we can get rid of the thread ident and just use the gident if it is causing a problem. For the mainthread (i.e. not in a greenthread), the gident should be == to the thread id, so it will be unique.

self.tname = "-%x" % gident & 0xffffffff

should be fine.'}, {'account_id': 67, 'date': '2012-04-02 19:39:24.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

This is an acceptable fix as well.'}, {'account_id': 679, 'date': '2012-04-10 20:35:17.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Looks good to me (core reviewer); Approved

'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-04-10 21:52:17.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Verified

Build Successful 
 
https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-integration-tests-devstack-vm/3404/ : SUCCESS 
https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-nova-merge/2207/ : SUCCESS 
https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-nova-unittests/1864/ : SUCCESS 
https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-nova-pep8/3600/ : SUCCESS'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-04-10 21:52:19.000000000', 'content': 'Change has been successfully merged into the git repository.'}]

commit_message:
fix TypeError with unstarted threads in nova-network

(nova): TRACE: File "/usr/lib64/python2.6/site-packages/nova/utils.py",
line 860, in __init__
(nova): TRACE: self.tname = "-%x-%x" % (ident & 0xffffffff, gident &
0xffffffff)
(nova): TRACE: TypeError: unsupported operand type(s) for &: 'NoneType'
and 'int'

Fixes: bug 971629

commit_message:
Fixed bug 962840, added a test case.

eventlet.tpool.Proxy doesn't work with old-style class in __str__()
or __repr__() calls. See bug #962840 for details.
We perform a monkey patch to replace those two instance methods.

Change-Id: Ia51bbd3e71cad7df45da5b3b27eef70f9d9e9002

commit_message:
Fixed the subcommand error message for nova shell.

Previously we were giving advice like this:

"Try 'nova volume-show help' for more information."

Bad advice -- that doesn't work. Now when there's a subcommand
specified we make a proper suggestion:

"Try 'nova help volume-show' for more information."

Change-Id: I6ef49f9e4e1b67074f51ab442abd4a196d437b00

commit_message:
Backport tox support for CI.

Add tox.ini file.

The tox.ini drives the current test suite in multiple virtual envs, so this
is a first step in trying to get multi-version testing.

Prep tox config for jenkins builds.

Add a generic tox build environment.

Allow for the running of arbitrary commands inside of a venv
so that we don't have to make tox envs for every blessed thing we want to
do.

Align to jenkins tox patterns.

Split requires in to pip-requires and test-requires.
Updated install_venv to know about test-requires.

Update tox.ini for jenkins.

The tox documentation is wrong, it looks for [tox:jenkins] instead
of [tox:hudson].  Also, run "pip freeze" before running tests from
within the virtualenv so we have a record of all versions used
in each test run in Jenkins.

Fix typo in tox.ini.

My last commit message was right, the code was wrong.  It's tox:jenkins.
Commands are invalid in tox: sections, so we'll get pip freeze run
another way.

Change-Id: I9c28ee11aa7bbe1b221a72e0ee8cc51d788f73c9

subject: Add the serialization of exceptions for RPC calls.
reviewers: [{'_account_id': 3, 'name': 'Jenkins', 'username': 'jenkins'}, {'_account_id': 67, 'name': 'Vish Ishaya', 'email': 'vishvananda@gmail.com', 'username': 'vishvananda'}, {'_account_id': 100, 'name': 'Johannes Erdfelt', 'email': 'johannes@erdfelt.com', 'username': 'johannes.erdfelt'}, {'_account_id': 177, 'name': 'Alex Meade', 'email': 'mr.alex.meade@gmail.com', 'username': 'alex-meade'}, {'_account_id': 688, 'name': 'Sandy Walsh', 'email': 'sandy.walsh@rackspace.com', 'username': 'sandy-walsh'}, {'_account_id': 1030, 'name': 'Chris Behrens', 'email': 'cbehrens@codestud.com', 'username': 'cbehrens'}, {'_account_id': 2166, 'name': 'SmokeStack CI', 'username': 'smokestack', 'tags': ['SERVICE_USER']}]
messages:
[{'account_id': 100, 'date': '2012-03-23 20:22:39.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

(3 inline comments)

"}, {'account_id': 67, 'date': '2012-03-23 20:42:20.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

Very cool stuff. Any way we can sanitize into json instead of pickle? Pickle allows arbitrary code execution. We are already in a lot of trouble if someone has access to the rabbit queue, but it still would be nice to limit their potential attacks instead of giving them a free pass to the entire system.

Example:

http://penturalabs.wordpress.com/2011/03/17/python-cpickle-allows-for-arbitrary-code-execution/"}, {'account_id': 1030, 'date': '2012-03-23 20:59:24.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

I also would prefer this to not be pickle, because I'm not sure it should be a requirement that workers are written in Python.  I'd thought about doing this exact patch before, but I held back for this reason.  Would appreciate others thoughts on this..."}, {'account_id': 100, 'date': '2012-03-23 21:08:40.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

I'm fine with using pickle. The data is trusted and reimplementing pickle in JSON is just busy work right now.

There is no defined API or protocol for API calls, so the implementation is effectively the API.

I'm sure that creating a worker that isn't part of the nova codebase (let alone isn't Python) would be a large amount of work right now.

I'd be fine with defining the RPC API/protocol to allow for other implementations, but that is much bigger than this change."}, {'account_id': 100, 'date': '2012-03-23 21:10:11.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Err, that should read:

"There is no defined API or protocol for *RPC* calls, so the implementation is effectively the API."

Also, my -1 is for a couple of minor changes I'd like to see, not with the purpose of the patch in general :)'}, {'account_id': 177, 'date': '2012-03-26 17:46:55.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: (3 inline comments)

Vish: Great catch, I can't believe it'll just run commands! I have found an easy way to make sure that the class is an exception before pickle creates any instances or runs any commands. I'll push up a patch set with those changes.

If we were to use json we would still need to keep the same concern in mind.

Behrens: Pickle is deserializing the exceptions into python exceptions anyway, if it fails then it will act as it currently does."}, {'account_id': 100, 'date': '2012-03-26 17:57:27.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: (1 inline comment)

I'm not sure I understand what you mean by "If we were to use json we would still need to keep the same concern in mind.".

JSON deserializers won't execute arbitrary code during the deserialization process. Or at least, if they are implemented correctly they shouldn't :)

Unfortunately, pickle will by design.

Can you explain your solution a bit more? It sounds like you're checking before pickling to solve the problem, whereas the security concern is on the unpickling side.'}, {'account_id': 177, 'date': '2012-03-26 18:26:29.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

I'm actually checking as it unpickles, tested and working, but I think I am just going to reimplement this with JSON after all. That way it will end up more straight forward and we wont have these problems."}, {'account_id': 100, 'date': '2012-03-26 18:35:23.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

I'm still unsure this is even a problem considering the implicit trust in the network anyway.

But I'd agree it would make more sense to use JSON than to go out of your way to "fix" pickle.'}, {'account_id': 177, 'date': '2012-03-26 20:37:49.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 177, 'date': '2012-03-26 20:38:13.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

phew much better, thanks for the input guys'}, {'account_id': 100, 'date': '2012-03-26 21:02:35.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

(2 inline comments)

"}, {'account_id': 177, 'date': '2012-03-26 21:57:29.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 100, 'date': '2012-03-26 22:02:15.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

(1 inline comment)

'}, {'account_id': 67, 'date': '2012-03-27 00:00:06.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Do not submit

I think the deserialization is still unsafe.  I think we should probably wrap all base exceptions in a NovaException and force a check that the incoming exception module is an allowed class before constructing it.

Doing a quick test to verify that it is insecure as is.'}, {'account_id': 67, 'date': '2012-03-27 00:20:36.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

vishvananda@firefly-2:~/os/nova (review/alex_meade/bug/920705)$ python
Python 2.7.2 (default, Feb 29 2012, 18:42:29) 
[GCC 4.2.1 (Based on Apple Inc. build 5658) (LLVM build 2335.15.00)] on darwin
Type "help", "copyright", "credits" or "license" for more information.
>>> from nova.rpc import common
>>> import json
>>> data = {'module': 'os', 'class': 'popen2', 'message': 'foo', 'tb': 'bar', 'kwargs': {'cmd': '/bin/echo pwned > foo.txt | dummy'}}
>>> common.deserialize_remote_exception(json.dumps(data))
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<stdin>", line 1, in <module>
  File "nova/rpc/common.py", line 223, in deserialize_remote_exception
    failure.args = (message,) + failure.args[1:]
AttributeError: 'tuple' object has no attribute 'args'
>>> /bin/sh: dummy: command not found

vishvananda@firefly-2:~/os/nova (review/alex_meade/bug/920705)$ cat foo.txt
pwned'}, {'account_id': 67, 'date': '2012-03-27 00:40:35.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

This will fix the immediate issues, unless there are exceptions in the system that allow arbitrary code execution:

diff --git a/nova/rpc/common.py b/nova/rpc/common.py
index e70bc85..8ae2050 100644
--- a/nova/rpc/common.py
+++ b/nova/rpc/common.py
@@ -202,10 +202,13 @@ def deserialize_remote_exception(data):
     mod = sys.modules[failure['module']]
     try:
         klass = getattr(mod, name)
+        if not issubclass(Exception, klass):
+            return RemoteError(failure['class'], failure['message'], failure['tb'])
         failure = klass(**failure['kwargs'])
-    except AttributeError:
+    except (AttributeError, TypeError):
         return RemoteError(failure['class'], failure['message'], failure['tb'])
 
+
     ex_type = type(failure)
     str_override = lambda self: message
     new_ex_type = type(ex_type.__name__ + "_Remote", (ex_type,),

all of the failure['class'], failure['message'], etc. calls should also be changed to gets: failure.get('class') etc.  Someone could still exploit this by getting a specially constructed exception into the python path and then deserializing that exception.  It might be a little insane to go that far though. If we want to get extra safe, we could force it to only work with exceptions defined in nova.exception. The disadvantage of this is third party plugins/extensions would not be able to send exceptions through the queue.'}, {'account_id': 177, 'date': '2012-03-27 02:38:05.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

Ah yeah this is exactly how pickle was insecure. Should we just allow any exception? I'm not sure I am comfortable with that. We could have a list of modules that we allow and include 'exceptions', 'nova.exceptions' and any others we deem safe, just hate that it would be another thing to keep up with."}, {'account_id': 67, 'date': '2012-03-27 05:26:42.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

Tough choice.  Perhaps the best is to wrap any non-nova exception on the calling side In a NovaException of some sort (RemoteError?) and not pass in the module name (force the module name to be nova.exception).  This seems the safest, and loses some flexibilty for third party plugins, but i don't think it is too harsh.

If that seems too limiting. I would also be ok with a flag for allowed_exception_modules that defaults to [nova.exception] but can be added to by deployers in case they want to add some third party exception library.

It would be great for some other security-minded folks to weigh in."}, {'account_id': 67, 'date': '2012-03-27 05:28:03.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

Woah, didn't mean to switch that to lgtm"}, {'account_id': 177, 'date': '2012-03-27 19:39:23.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

I like the flag idea.

There are a number of places within nova where exceptions are defined, besides nova.exception. So we would either wrap those, put them in the flag, or move them into nova.exception.

Also, there are a few places that depend on the type of exception that is returned from the call. We wouldn't want to break those if the exception's module wasn't specified in the flag.

Thoughts on that?"}, {'account_id': 177, 'date': '2012-03-28 18:28:40.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 177, 'date': '2012-03-28 18:31:16.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4:

Thanks a lot for your help, Vish. I added a flag that defaults to ['nova.exception'] and I also added the check to make sure the class is a subclass of exception. I can't foresee any problems with this besides someone adding things willy nilly to the flag or sneaking unsafe code into nova.exceptions, but I've been wrong before."}, {'account_id': 67, 'date': '2012-03-31 00:39:44.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

Nice much more secure.

I have one remaining concern.  When you recreate the original exception, you lose the original traceback. Someone could theoretically check the remote side and find the original, but it won't be obvious.  I'm thinking something like the following might be useful:

Add an extra kwarg param to NovaException called remote_tb or some such.  Save the original traceback into the new exception when you recreate it.  Modify logging to print out the original traceback as well as the current traceback if it exists.  That way we still are displaying the original traceback in addition to the current one which will always be the line in deserialize in the rpc module."}, {'account_id': 177, 'date': '2012-03-31 04:42:57.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

The original traceback is being appended to the message of the exception, so it should be logged no matter what.'}, {'account_id': 67, 'date': '2012-03-31 22:00:55.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4:

Alex:  I don't see where that is happening:

	220	        failure = klass(**failure.get('kwargs', {}))

it looks like it is just the original kwargs that are being passed to the reconstructed exception.  I'd like to have access to the traceback on the calling side. Please direct me to the code if I'm overlooking something."}, {'account_id': 177, 'date': '2012-04-02 18:23:49.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

rpc/common.py

204	    message = failure.get('message', "") + "\n" + "\n".join(trace)

..

224	    ex_type = type(failure)
225	    str_override = lambda self: message
226	    new_ex_type = type(ex_type.__name__ + "_Remote", (ex_type,),
227	                       {'__str__': str_override})


In test_common I assert that the original traceback was added to the exception.'}, {'account_id': 688, 'date': '2012-04-02 20:16:03.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4: (3 inline comments)

Some minor questions. Tests pass.

I guess I'm trying to understand the motivation of the branch. Isn't getting a RemoteError sufficient? What's the use case where we'd prefer to know exactly what failed?

Seems that where we have to check for RemoteError anyway it's just going to make the calling code more complicated?

I'm sure I'm just missing something."}, {'account_id': 67, 'date': '2012-04-02 20:25:25.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

Ok I'm satisfied.  Thanks alex."}, {'account_id': 177, 'date': '2012-04-04 15:34:12.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: (2 inline comments)

'}, {'account_id': 688, 'date': '2012-04-06 15:59:32.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4: Looks good to me (core reviewer); Approved

I'm cool with this now after talking with the guys in IRC."}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-04-06 16:29:10.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Fails

Build Failed

https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-nova-pep8/3558/ : FAILURE'}, {'account_id': 177, 'date': '2012-04-06 16:46:03.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 5.'}, {'account_id': 688, 'date': '2012-04-06 17:30:58.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

commit_message:
Add the serialization of exceptions for RPC calls.

This change uses json to serialize an exception so that it can be sent
through RPC calls to be reconstructed on the other side. The traceback is added
to the exception message. If recreating the exception fails for whatever reason
then a RemoteError is created containing all of the exception information.

Adds flag 'allowed_rpc_exception_modules' to prevent dangerous modules from
being accessed and allowing arbitrary code to be run.

Fixes bug 920705
Fixes bug 940500

Change-Id: Ife3b64b19fe8abbc730184d4ee7d9fcabfd29db3

Improve grammar throughout nova.

Fixes some "its" and "it's" mistakes, and unifies the tense of
some documentation.

subject: Standardize quota flag format
messages:
[{'account_id': 679, 'date': '2012-04-10 15:29:10.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

I'll point out that we have two distinct classes of quotas.  One class (instances, cores, ram, volumes, gigabytes, and floating_ips) provides a limit on the total number of the respective resource, while the other class (metadata_items, injected_files, injected_file_content_bytes, and injected_file_path_bytes) provides a relative limit—i.e., you can have at most 10 instances, but for each of them you can inject at most 5 files.  Currently, we have no convention for differentiating between them."}, {'account_id': 100, 'date': '2012-04-10 15:36:55.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Looks good to me (core reviewer); Approved

'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-04-10 16:04:19.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Fails

Build Failed 
 
https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-integration-tests-devstack-vm/3375/ : FAILURE 
https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-nova-merge/2194/ : SUCCESS 
https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-nova-unittests/1851/ : SUCCESS 
https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-nova-pep8/3587/ : SUCCESS'}, {'account_id': 1849, 'date': '2012-04-10 16:35:25.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Kevin,

Thats a very good point.  How do you propose distinguishing between the two classes of quota flags?    Presumably some way of saying that the second class is per VM.'}, {'account_id': 679, 'date': '2012-04-10 16:42:31.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: No score

The way I'm doing it in my quota refactor is simply the presence or absence of a "sync" routine defined on the resource, but I haven't really thought about differentiating them in the name.  If we decide we need to do that, one option might be to use the 'max_' prefix convention, but I'm not 100% convinced that we need to from the standpoint of users…'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-04-10 19:21:49.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Verified

https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-integration-tests-devstack-vm/3391/ : SUCCESS'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-04-10 19:21:51.000000000', 'content': 'Change has been successfully merged into the git repository.'}]

The localization testing is required. If you want to put it in tools/hacking.py, we would have to turn on the the HACKING conformance tests by default. We don't currently enforce HACKING very well, so I'm not sure that's a good path forward. You will need to make sure the localization tests are always run (not just when the --just-hacking flag is on) to get this review to land. Please correct me if I've misunderstood anything."}, {'account_id': 708, 'date': '2012-03-12 17:24:32.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

Brian,

there are two changes currently in review that cover all HACKING problems was found by tools/hacking.py.

We can use tools/hacking.py instead of pep8 run since it actually extends pep8. When that changes land, we can enforce pep8 and land this one too. I don't see any problem in that.

Johannes,

totally forgot about your comment. Will merge this change with yours shortly."}, {'account_id': 708, 'date': '2012-03-12 19:37:17.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 100, 'date': '2012-03-12 22:04:06.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4:

seems like it is valuable to add hacking.py to the gate.'}, {'account_id': 642, 'date': '2012-03-13 21:05:37.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

commit_message:
Add -i/--identity option to 'nova ssh'.

Add an option for specify a private key to use with 'nova ssh'.  '-i'
was chosen to match the option this maps to in ssh.

Change-Id: Iecb2a20a34816e8f1ea80c1f66fac476037a798f

subject: Adding timeout decorator for tests
reviewers: [{'_account_id': 67, 'name': 'Vish Ishaya', 'email': 'vishvananda@gmail.com', 'username': 'vishvananda'}, {'_account_id': 100, 'name': 'Johannes Erdfelt', 'email': 'johannes@erdfelt.com', 'username': 'johannes.erdfelt'}, {'_account_id': 679, 'name': 'Kevin L. Mitchell', 'email': 'klmitch@mit.edu', 'username': 'klmitch'}, {'_account_id': 1030, 'name': 'Chris Behrens', 'email': 'cbehrens@codestud.com', 'username': 'cbehrens'}, {'_account_id': 1456, 'name': 'Aaron Lee', 'email': 'aaron.lee@rackspace.com', 'username': 'aaron-lee'}, {'_account_id': 1561, 'name': 'Russell Bryant', 'email': 'rbryant@redhat.com', 'username': 'russellb'}, {'_account_id': 2166, 'name': 'SmokeStack CI', 'username': 'smokestack', 'tags': ['SERVICE_USER']}]
messages:
[{'account_id': 100, 'date': '2012-04-03 19:58:23.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: (1 inline comment)

Is there a bug opened on the original problem?'}, {'account_id': 679, 'date': '2012-04-03 20:08:16.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

I think I agree with Johannes here; the exception could be moved to test.py.  Or raise an AssertionError instead; that would allow you to declare the test a "failure" instead of an "error"—your preference.'}, {'account_id': 1561, 'date': '2012-04-03 20:08:21.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

Yeah, if these tests are trying to contact the broker, something is wrong.  IIRC, they should be using the in-memory transport from kombu."}, {'account_id': 1030, 'date': '2012-04-03 20:31:47.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

The tests use the memory transport of kombu... and doesn't try to contact any remote service.

I think there's potentially a race condition bug in the memory transport, however."}, {'account_id': 1456, 'date': '2012-04-03 20:40:03.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

If that is the case I will keep digging. I've only seen these issues with systems that do not have RabbitMQ installed. I checked with several other developers that have said they have seen the same issue, I added this timeout to raise a proper exception instead of hanging."}, {'account_id': 67, 'date': '2012-04-03 21:59:46.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

If we have tests that are hanging due to rabbit not being installed, I would prefer to use a skip decorator like we do for the libvirt tests.  AFAIK this should not be the case though."}, {'account_id': 1456, 'date': '2012-04-10 18:27:54.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Abandoned

I've raised lp974411 to see if anyone else has these issues. Until we get ore information this change is abandon."}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2012-04-03 19:54:44.000000000', 'message': 'Adding timeout decorator for tests

Some of the kombu tests can hang. The proper
solution is to not test interaction with remote
systems in a unit test. This timer is a stopgap to
keep the tests from just hanging. (In my ideal
world this would be wrapped around every test with
a timeout of 1, but we have some work to do before
getting there)

Change-Id: Icf1c2dcc2066e52c9fbe5f5c097fb6ea71218b24
'}]
commit_message:
Adding timeout decorator for tests

Some of the kombu tests can hang. The proper
solution is to not test interaction with remote
systems in a unit test. This timer is a stopgap to
keep the tests from just hanging. (In my ideal
world this would be wrapped around every test with
a timeout of 1, but we have some work to do before
getting there)

Change-Id: Icf1c2dcc2066e52c9fbe5f5c097fb6ea71218b24

commit_message:

commit_message:
Add validation on quota limits (negative numbers).

Quotas should not accept negative numbers other than -1.

Fixes LP Bug #973034.

Change-Id: Icc647d80df42d09928717d48ae95dfc8b76c4795

commit_message:
Use thread local storage from openstack.common.

nova.local was recently added to openstack-common.  Remove nova.local
and use openstack.common.local instead.

One benefit of this change is that it is another step toward decoupling
nova.rpc from the rest of nova.

Change-Id: I0240f4291a81f8390d3f329a11f207a1453d7cab

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-03-15 17:30:09.000000000', 'message': 'Add support for local.sh and unstack.sh

Run local.sh at the end of stack.sh if it exists and is executable.
This allows the user to automatically perform local actions on every
re-stack, such as creating custom flavors or specific tenants/users.
Like localrc, this file is not distributed with DevStack so user
modifications will be undisturbed.

unstack.sh is a simple clean-up script to kill known running
OpenStack processes.

is_service_enabled() moves to functions

Change-Id: I41b33817c4436e644c336e4e0673144ac0844c26
'}, {'created': '2012-03-27 18:48:33.000000000', 'message': 'Add support for local.sh and add unstack.sh

Run local.sh at the end of stack.sh if it exists and is executable.
This allows the user to automatically perform local actions on every
re-stack, such as creating custom flavors or specific tenants/users.
Like localrc, this file is not distributed with DevStack so user
modifications will be undisturbed.

unstack.sh is a simple clean-up script to kill known running
OpenStack processes.

is_service_enabled() moves to functions

Change-Id: I41b33817c4436e644c336e4e0673144ac0844c26
'}, {'created': '2012-03-28 16:25:25.000000000', 'message': 'Add unstack.sh

unstack.sh is a simple clean-up script to kill known running
OpenStack processes:
* screen
* swift daemons
* apache
* volumes

Change-Id: I41b33817c4436e644c336e4e0673144ac0844c26
'}, {'created': '2012-03-28 23:05:15.000000000', 'message': "Add unstack.sh

unstack.sh is a simple clean-up script to kill known running
OpenStack processes:
* quit devstack's screen session
* stop swift daemons
* stop apache
* remove volumes

Change-Id: I41b33817c4436e644c336e4e0673144ac0844c26
"}]
commit_message:
Add unstack.sh

unstack.sh is a simple clean-up script to kill known running
OpenStack processes:
* quit devstack's screen session
* stop swift daemons
* stop apache
* remove volumes

Change-Id: I41b33817c4436e644c336e4e0673144ac0844c26

commit_message:
Allow instance logging to use just a UUID.

Sometimes all you have is an instance UUID, and its not worth
building an instance dict just for logging. Allow callers to pass
just the UUID if that's all they have. Resolves bug 975774.

I have included a sample use as well.

Change-Id: I1eb50515d837869ed7fdc5e766d8700be7da3286

commit_message:
Allow unprivileged RADOS users to access rbd volumes.

This makes it possible to access rbd volumes with RADOS users with
restricted privileges. Previously, the admin user was always used.

This requires libvirt 0.9.8 or higher.

This is a backport of commit 01f24caba86c987b0109f743979a4e99e8afed11
from master.

Fixes bug 975335.

Change-Id: I3fbb2c03e5f63940c3a42f2d4f8d03ee16b30f7e

subject: Timeout support in execute. Fixes bug 968222.
messages:
[{'account_id': 1812, 'date': '2012-04-02 09:43:27.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

I've a few issues with this:

1. You can't replace subprocess.communicate() with a simple write(),read(),read() due to deadlock issues.

2. You don't kill any hung processes, just ignoring them if they take too long, which I think is dangerous. Have you any indication as to why qemu-nbd is hanging on umount, and does it eventually proceed?

3. Have you tried the libguestfs method instead?

4. You don't activate this logic anywhere in the patch.
Are you preparing a follow up to change qemu-nbd usage?

5. The `timeout` command is generally available now, so
it seems like it would be simpler to use that if needed.
I.E. just prepend ('timeout', 'value') to the command,
dealing with the timeout exit code of 124 if required."}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2012-04-10 06:03:13.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

code review expired after 1 week of no activity after a negative review'}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2012-04-10 06:03:14.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Abandoned

code review expired after 1 week of no activity after a negative review'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2012-04-02 08:51:39.000000000', 'message': 'Timeout support in execute. Fixes bug 968222.

1. Added support to specify command execution timeout (param name
process_timeout).
2. Added unit test coverage.

Change-Id: I85b4ee548d717014ab1e672ea5b20b42434f092b
'}]
commit_message:
Timeout support in execute. Fixes bug 968222.

1. Added support to specify command execution timeout (param name
process_timeout).
2. Added unit test coverage.

Change-Id: I85b4ee548d717014ab1e672ea5b20b42434f092b

subject: Including extensions_path option on quantum_client
reviewers: [{'_account_id': 3, 'name': 'Jenkins', 'username': 'jenkins'}, {'_account_id': 261, 'name': 'Salvatore Orlando', 'email': 'salv.orlando@gmail.com', 'username': 'salvatore-orlando'}, {'_account_id': 490, 'name': 'Sumit Naiksatam', 'email': 'sumitnaiksatam@gmail.com', 'username': 'snaiksat'}, {'_account_id': 2035, 'name': 'Maru Newby', 'email': 'marun@redhat.com', 'username': 'maru'}, {'_account_id': 2350, 'name': 'Willian Molinari', 'email': 'pothix@pothix.com', 'username': 'pothix'}, {'_account_id': 2487, 'name': 'Thiago Morello', 'email': 'morellon@gmail.com', 'username': 'morellon'}, {'_account_id': 2672, 'name': 'Madhav Puri', 'email': 'madhav.puri@gmail.com', 'username': 'madhav-puri'}]
messages:
[{'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-04-10 06:03:02.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Verified

Build Successful 
 
https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-python-quantumclient-merge/31/ : SUCCESS 
https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-python-quantumclient-pep8/32/ : SUCCESS'}, {'account_id': 490, 'date': '2012-04-10 06:03:02.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

I am trying to understand as well the requirement for this change. Is it so that the extensions can be accessed using the Quantum Client? If so, it was already possible to do this before by passing the URI argument and then calling do_request on the returned Client object.

Or may be I am missing something here!'}, {'account_id': 2035, 'date': '2012-04-10 06:03:02.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

(1 inline comment)

Good enough, but please avoid adding unrelated changes.

Also, please rely on others to review your code - a +1 to your own change isn't really applicable."}, {'account_id': 2350, 'date': '2012-04-10 06:03:02.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

We are using this feature write the client for our plugin, extending from Client class.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-04-10 06:03:02.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Verified

Build Successful 
 
https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-python-quantumclient-merge/32/ : SUCCESS'}, {'account_id': 261, 'date': '2012-04-10 06:03:02.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: No score

'}, {'account_id': 261, 'date': '2012-04-10 06:03:02.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

Hi William

I reckon that this patch is somehow related to the larger patch you on the L2/L3 plugin. I understand the rational behind this small change in the client library. 

However, I was wondering whether this is actually the way we would like to enhance the client for enabling extensions. An extension, at least in quantum terminology might have a different URI prefix but might also add attributes to an existing resource. 

It seems that using your patch the client will perform the same operations, but on a different URI. In other terms you will be completely bypassing the 'standard' core Quantum API and perform all the operations through the extensions. Is that correct?"}, {'account_id': 490, 'date': '2012-04-10 06:03:02.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Hi Willian, We have tried to leverage the existing client code to access extensions, an example is in this code:
https://github.com/openstack/quantum/blob/master/quantum/plugins/cisco/nova/vifdirect.py

Is it this that you are looking to achieve or is it something else?

Thanks!'}, {'account_id': 2035, 'date': '2012-04-10 06:03:02.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

Looks good.'}, {'account_id': 2350, 'date': '2012-04-10 06:03:02.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

ok. No +1 from me.
Removed the blank line too...'}, {'account_id': 2350, 'date': '2012-04-10 06:03:02.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Hi Sumit and Salvatore,

As I explained before, I tried to find a good way to implement our client based on the quantum one. My idea is to reuse the quantum client code (by inheritance) to implement our own code.

Following this implementation I don't need to change the client code. The only problem with this implementation is the extensions URL. When looking into the code I found this:

https://github.com/openstack/python-quantumclient/blob/master/quantum/client/__init__.py#L209

This line makes a lot of the client url, but it doesn't consider extensions URLs. (an example of our extension URL: http://$host_id:9696/v1.0/extensions/plugin/tenants/tenant/extension_resource.json).

This patch makes the quantumclient to accept the "extensions/plugin" URL, so it will be useful for extension developers.'}, {'account_id': 2350, 'date': '2012-04-10 06:03:02.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

Hi Summit!

Yes, coding on the way you showed works good.

I just want to create a new instance passing my extension_path to the constructor avoid passing it every time I call do_request, the idea is to delegate the extensions path handling to the Client and keep it working on the same way.

But you're correct, the plugins/extensions client could be made without this patch."}, {'account_id': 2350, 'date': '2012-04-10 06:03:02.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

Salvatore, 

The idea behind this patch is to inherit from the Client library to create the plugin client lib.

We are writing the client for our plugin and I couldn't find the best way to do it on the current quantum-client code. This patch allow us to use inheritance and reuse all the code on the Client class on our plugin, including our extensions that changes attributes for our own models.

This patch would allow others to do the same thing with their client libs, inherit from the client class."}, {'account_id': 2350, 'date': '2012-04-10 06:03:02.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Any idea about this one?'}, {'account_id': 2350, 'date': '2012-04-10 06:03:02.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

commit_message:
return 404 for invalid api version request

fixes bug: 934115

This fix returns 404 for all non-root requests that route via the
versions app. For root requests ('/') the available api version info is
returned.

Change-Id: I701389d9239cb40426f7a47206642b56c7eeeae1

commit_message:
Bootstrapping v2 Image API implementation

* Adding barebones of images, access, schema, and root resources
* Greatly simplify version negotiation middleware
* Partially implements bp api-2

Change-Id: I3ae72354d7ec7f3766aec164d305c52e7315200d

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-04-06 13:00:00.000000000', 'message': 'Cloudpipe tap vpn not always working

This is a fix for bug 975043

Since Essex, all instances will have an eth0 MAC address in the range
of FA:16:3E, which is near the end of the MAC address space.

(This was introduced by a fix for this bug: 921838)

When openvpn is started, a TAP interface is created with a random
generated MAC address. Chances are high the generated MAC address is
lower in value than the eth0 MAC address. Once the tap interface is
added to the bridge interface, the bridge interface will no longer have
the eth0 MAC address, but take over the TAP MAC address. This is a
feature of the linux kernel, whereby a bridge interface will take the
MAC address with the lowest value amongst its interfaces. After the ARP
entries expire, this will result in the cloudpipe instance being no
longer reachable.

This fix, randomly generates a MAC address starting with FC, which is
greater than FA, and will thus ensure the brige will keep the eth0 MAC
address.

Change-Id: I0bd994b6dc7a92738ed23cd62ee42a021fd394e2
'}, {'created': '2012-04-06 14:19:49.000000000', 'message': 'Cloudpipe tap vpn not always working

Add comment describing why we need a MAC address like this

Change-Id: I0bd994b6dc7a92738ed23cd62ee42a021fd394e2
'}, {'created': '2012-04-06 14:21:26.000000000', 'message': 'Cloudpipe tap vpn not always working

Remove some trailing white space

Change-Id: I0bd994b6dc7a92738ed23cd62ee42a021fd394e2
'}, {'created': '2012-04-08 14:18:56.000000000', 'message': 'Cloudpipe tap vpn not always working

Fixes bug 975043

Since Essex, all instances will have an eth0 MAC address in the range
of FA:16:3E, which is near the end of the MAC address space.

When openvpn is started, a TAP interface is created with a random
generated MAC address. Chances are high the generated MAC address is
lower in value than the eth0 MAC address. Once the tap interface is
added to the bridge interface, the bridge interface will no longer have
the eth0 MAC address, but take over the TAP MAC address. This is a
feature of the linux kernel, whereby a bridge interface will take the
MAC address with the lowest value amongst its interfaces. After the ARP
entries expire, this will result in the cloudpipe instance being no
longer reachable.

This fix, randomly generates a MAC address starting with FA:17:3E, which
is greater than FA, and will thus ensure the brige will keep the eth0 MAC
address.

Change-Id: I0bd994b6dc7a92738ed23cd62ee42a021fd394e2
'}]
commit_message:
Cloudpipe tap vpn not always working

Fixes bug 975043

Since Essex, all instances will have an eth0 MAC address in the range
of FA:16:3E, which is near the end of the MAC address space.

When openvpn is started, a TAP interface is created with a random
generated MAC address. Chances are high the generated MAC address is
lower in value than the eth0 MAC address. Once the tap interface is
added to the bridge interface, the bridge interface will no longer have
the eth0 MAC address, but take over the TAP MAC address. This is a
feature of the linux kernel, whereby a bridge interface will take the
MAC address with the lowest value amongst its interfaces. After the ARP
entries expire, this will result in the cloudpipe instance being no
longer reachable.

This fix, randomly generates a MAC address starting with FA:17:3E, which
is greater than FA, and will thus ensure the brige will keep the eth0 MAC
address.

Change-Id: I0bd994b6dc7a92738ed23cd62ee42a021fd394e2

Create compute.api.BaseAPI for compute APIs to use

Fixes bug 960226 where compute.api.HostAPI called non-existent methods

Added tests for HostAPI

commit_message:
Give all VDIs a reasonable name-label and name-description

Add image id to cached glance images as well as disk type so it's easy
to see if a VDI is an os, swap or ephemeral disk.

commit_message:
Remove unecessary --repeat option for pep8.

Fixes bug 977489

--repeat became the default in 0.7; since we're now requiring 1.0 or
above, this can go away.

Change-Id: I85ee8ab274594ce96ece6610247dfd8a6f082af5
