subject: HACKING fixes, sqlalchemy fix.
reviewers: [{'_account_id': 3, 'name': 'Jenkins', 'username': 'jenkins'}, {'_account_id': 67, 'name': 'Vish Ishaya', 'email': 'vishvananda@gmail.com', 'username': 'vishvananda'}, {'_account_id': 100, 'name': 'Johannes Erdfelt', 'email': 'johannes@erdfelt.com', 'username': 'johannes.erdfelt'}, {'_account_id': 236, 'name': 'Monsyne Dragon', 'email': 'mdragon@rackspace.com', 'username': 'mdragon'}, {'_account_id': 308, 'name': 'Thierry Carrez', 'email': 'thierry@openstack.org', 'username': 'ttx'}, {'_account_id': 642, 'name': 'Matt Dietz', 'email': 'matthew.dietz@gmail.com', 'username': 'cerberus'}, {'_account_id': 679, 'name': 'Kevin L. Mitchell', 'email': 'klmitch@mit.edu', 'username': 'klmitch'}, {'_account_id': 708, 'name': 'Yuriy Taraday', 'email': 'yorik.sar@gmail.com', 'username': 'yorik-sar'}, {'_account_id': 1849, 'name': 'Joe Gordon', 'email': 'joe.gordon0@gmail.com', 'username': 'jogo'}, {'_account_id': 2035, 'name': 'Maru Newby', 'email': 'marun@redhat.com', 'username': 'maru'}, {'_account_id': 2166, 'name': 'SmokeStack CI', 'username': 'smokestack', 'tags': ['SERVICE_USER']}]
messages:
[{'account_id': 2035, 'date': '2012-03-06 00:12:17.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Why do sqlalchemy.orm classes like Column and have to be module-prefixed rather than just imported?  Model declaration in SQLAlchemy is one of the few times 'import *' might be justified to reduce the incidence of boilerplate, and this patch appears to be going in exactly the opposite direction."}, {'account_id': 708, 'date': '2012-03-06 06:38:44.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

We should totally honor HACKING - no class imports.
It doesn't actually add too much lines or code, does it?"}, {'account_id': 2035, 'date': '2012-03-06 07:45:30.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Yes, the hacking file does specify no object imports.  And there is a good reason for such a rule - importing objects risks circular import problems.  But for a 3rd party library like SQLAlchemy, when are circular imports ever going to be an issue?  I would appreciate a core-reviewer's feedback, but my opinion is that adding unnecessary verbosity for the sake of a rule that probably doesn't apply is a bad idea.  Pragmatism not idealism, please."}, {'account_id': 708, 'date': '2012-03-06 08:19:33.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

We force this rule even for stdlib. There is at least one reason besides circular imports - mocking. If we ever want to mock anything in stdlib or 3rd-party lib, we'll have problems if objects are imported from these libs by name.

Although, for sqlalchemy we can make an exception, but we should be really sure that we'll never use sqlalchemy outside nova.db.sqlalchemy.
BTW, if you look in tools/hacking.py, line 70:

    BAD: from sqlalchemy import MetaData, Table

I guess, Joe Gordon (looks like this script is his child) explicitly wrote about this case.

Anyway, someone from core team can decide on this while we can look through previous change that has a lot bigger impact."}, {'account_id': 2035, 'date': '2012-03-06 08:30:22.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Can you please elaborate on how mocking could induce circular imports?  I lack the imagination to see how this is possible.'}, {'account_id': 708, 'date': '2012-03-06 08:34:55.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

No, no circular imports, but just fail.

a.py

  B = 5

b.py

  from a import B

  def f():
    print B

Now if you do in tests something like this (a la mocking):

  a.B = 10
  f()

Then f will always print 5 because B is fixed in module b.'}, {'account_id': 708, 'date': '2012-03-06 08:56:36.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 100, 'date': '2012-03-06 16:15:14.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

I too am concerned that HACKING is too strict in this case. Code is about readability and I think adding prefixes will bloat out the code for no real reason instead of conforming to HACKING.

Can we fix the imports to follow HACKING, but then set the short keywords like we had before?

    import sqlalchemy

    and_, or_ = sqlalchemy.and_, sqlalchemy.or_"}, {'account_id': 708, 'date': '2012-03-06 16:17:34.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

I think, we should not use this pattern to trick checker. If we want it to be happy, we should either import only modules or add an exception for sqlalchemy module.'}, {'account_id': 100, 'date': '2012-03-06 16:35:30.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

It's not solely to trick checker is it? It would also solve any mocking problems like you had outlined.

Yeah it's unlikely to happen for sqlalchemy so I'm fine either making an exception or redefining into module variables."}, {'account_id': 708, 'date': '2012-03-06 16:45:21.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

It will not solve mocking problem at all since it is just from..import written in verbose form.

You can not mock any object that is somehow directly referenced.

  class C(object):
    a = 2
  c = C.a

After this you can not assign smth temporary to C.a to see how the code that uses c goes, because c does not reference to C.a but only to the object that was there when "c = C.a" was executed. So if we use that import pattern, and_ and or_ will be fixed after the module is imported and if we are to mock them in our module that is a very bad way to test stuff.'}, {'account_id': 100, 'date': '2012-03-06 16:56:38.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

Ahh, I misunderstood. Thanks for the reminder how Python works.

It's still possible to mock out those symbols, it would just need to be mocked out in the module that uses them instead of where they are declared.

Which is a bit awkward and non-standard and I'd like to avoid.

Anyway, if we do ever need to mock out sqlalchemy, we can change the modules that use it at that time. This isn't something that needs to be done just in case mocking is ever needed.

I'm still for an exception but that will require some consensus from other core devs."}, {'account_id': 236, 'date': '2012-03-07 01:03:44.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

Hmm...  I also think that HACKING is too strict in this case. It can be problematic, especially in the case of classes from external libraries that are used effectively as data types. sqlalchemy's table and column types, netaddr's IPAddress class, datetime.datetime(), etc are examples of this. 

In those cases, we are not going to be mocking netaddr.IPAddress, or sqlalchemy's internal Table class. 

I would recommend HACKING make an exception for classes, or at least external classes. (We still should not import instance values directly, or constants.)"}, {'account_id': 236, 'date': '2012-03-07 01:08:28.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

I would also say, that this patch really makes the sqlalchemy model class definitions in particular hard to read and overly verbose. (the changes to the api file looks sensable, tho.)"}, {'account_id': 708, 'date': '2012-03-11 15:09:01.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 679, 'date': '2012-03-12 15:20:13.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

(2 inline comments)

Looks good except for the backslashes…"}, {'account_id': 708, 'date': '2012-03-12 16:27:30.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

I really don't see why backslashes are so bad. They're as valid and maybe even more readable than parenthesis all around.

I think, this Lisp-style "))))" is worse that a single backslash here and there and should be avoided.'}, {'account_id': 679, 'date': '2012-03-13 15:58:06.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

From PEP-0008:

    The preferred way of wrapping long lines is by using Python's implied line
    continuation inside parentheses, brackets and braces.  Long lines can be
    broken over multiple lines by wrapping expressions in parentheses. These
    should be used in preference to using a backslash for line continuation.
    Make sure to indent the continued line appropriately.  The preferred place
    to break around a binary operator is *after* the operator, not before it.

http://www.python.org/dev/peps/pep-0008/"}, {'account_id': 100, 'date': '2012-03-13 16:04:01.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

I'm not a fan of blindly following PEP8, especially when we ignore it in other areas (docstrings).

Since PEP8 doesn't give a rationale for it's suggestion to use parentheses, it's effectively religious dogma. You can't argue against it because it doesn't provide any reason for it.

I do have a rationale against using parentheses, it looks too much like a tuple. Backslashes never have that problem."}, {'account_id': 679, 'date': '2012-03-13 16:07:40.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

I don't see it as too onerous for either of these cases.  In particular, in the instance in nova_one_import_per_line(), there's one case where there are already parentheses, so backslash continuation is not used…yet on the next line, there are no surrounding parentheses, and so it is used."}, {'account_id': 100, 'date': '2012-03-13 16:14:24.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

I still don't see how using parentheses will keep them from looking like tuples.

Either way, it's probably a discussion best suited for somewhere other than a gerrit review :)"}, {'account_id': 642, 'date': '2012-03-13 16:55:22.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

To be fair, I've never once seen the parenthesis and been confused by their intent. The major issue at hand here is consistency, and arguing that we don't always follow the convention and so should continue to deviate is a little bit of a broken window. However, I also don't think it's that big of a deal, and this patch provides nice cleanup otherwise."}, {'account_id': 679, 'date': '2012-03-13 17:03:23.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: No score

OK, I still want the backslashes gone, but I won't hold this patch up with a -1 any longer."}, {'account_id': 708, 'date': '2012-03-14 03:26:11.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 708, 'date': '2012-03-14 03:27:59.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4:

I've added migrate module to exceptions to calm hacking.py down on migrations."}, {'account_id': 708, 'date': '2012-03-14 03:29:15.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 5.'}, {'account_id': 308, 'date': '2012-03-16 11:01:24.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

Only bugfixes should land in RC timeframe.

See discussion at:
https://bugs.launchpad.net/nova/+bug/956457"}, {'account_id': 308, 'date': '2012-03-16 13:55:23.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5:

The commit message is very misleading and should be updated.

Looking more closely, this looks fairly self-contained. I still think it makes more sense at Folsom start than at Essex end, but I won't veto it, if nova-core wants it in."}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2012-03-24 06:03:20.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

code review expired after 1 week of no activity after a negative review'}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2012-03-24 06:03:23.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Abandoned

code review expired after 1 week of no activity after a negative review'}, {'account_id': 708, 'date': '2012-04-09 14:03:02.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5:

Why don't we finish this?"}, {'account_id': 708, 'date': '2012-04-09 14:03:55.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Restored'}, {'account_id': 708, 'date': '2012-04-09 14:04:10.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 6.'}, {'account_id': 1849, 'date': '2012-04-09 16:10:40.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

'}, {'account_id': 67, 'date': '2012-04-09 18:16:10.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

seems reasonable.'}, {'account_id': 100, 'date': '2012-04-09 20:33:27.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6: Looks good to me (core reviewer); Approved

'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-04-09 20:44:24.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 6: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

messages:
[{'account_id': 7, 'date': '2012-03-30 19:17:40.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

sure, why not. I think eventually, as a community, we're going to need to decide whether (or to what level) we are going to do ome predictive analysis on which columns should be indexed in the default database schema.

Either that, or we do like this commit, and address the columns when they appear as poorly performing queries in real-world deployments?

-jay"}, {'account_id': 2750, 'date': '2012-04-09 18:56:57.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 7, 'date': '2012-04-09 20:09:45.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-03-12 21:46:58.000000000', 'message': 'Move (cast|call)_compute_message methods back into compute API class

Those calls need to be able to be overridden in a subclass to support
compute cells, at least initially.  A prior patch that moved them to
module functions broke the cells work.

Change-Id: I6c35fa1ac646fe686bbc2c5eed2da7e286d32a15
'}]
commit_message:
Move (cast|call)_compute_message methods back into compute API class

Those calls need to be able to be overridden in a subclass to support
compute cells, at least initially.  A prior patch that moved them to
module functions broke the cells work.

Change-Id: I6c35fa1ac646fe686bbc2c5eed2da7e286d32a15

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-04-09 18:21:48.000000000', 'message': "Use 'root' instead of 'os' in XenAPI driver

Instance types define disk names as root, swap and ephemeral. The
XenAPI driver however uses os, swap and ephemeral. Standardize on
calling them 'root' disks instead of 'os' disks.

Change-Id: Ia34346d463d06cb971537c305602926ceb0dc175
"}]
commit_message:
Use 'root' instead of 'os' in XenAPI driver

Instance types define disk names as root, swap and ephemeral. The
XenAPI driver however uses os, swap and ephemeral. Standardize on
calling them 'root' disks instead of 'os' disks.

Change-Id: Ia34346d463d06cb971537c305602926ceb0dc175

commit_message:
D) Reorganize top of stack.sh

Pull stack.sh sanity check reorg from multi-distro branch.
This performs OS detection checks earlier and moves the
Sanity Check section later so we have more information available.

Change-Id: I5b9e64c4dc024a9ad90bd4f7e5ed86d601c0f610

commit_message:
Fixes LP 973338 - Add custom alt and admin manager

* Adds new AltManager, AdminManager derived manager classes
* Allows Manager to be inited with custom credentials
* Adds config.ComputeAdminConfig class and setup
* Updates test_authorization to use AltManager class

Change-Id: Iff5b20fbdfb8979a775f30f7e07d6e06b29e6c1c

commit_message:
C) Move swift defaults for config & data

* change config vars _LOCATION to _DIR to be consistient with other vars
* let config files live in /etc/swift like they want to
* move swift backing files to $DEST/data/swift

Change-Id: Idbd507736b46c5c2330e0255cc87f40068d3faf6

commit_message:
Introduced option to delete deallocated ips immediately. Fixes bug
971504

New flag allows deleting IPs soon on deallocation. This removes the
need to run external script manually or via cron. Get old beaviour by
setting the falg to True.

Added test case for this beahviour.

Change-Id: Ife04dd85ed311e806b790f6d1487a963dd3a05af

Hi Brian,

I'm having trouble understanding all the changes that involve removing trailing slashes... could you explain why those are necessary?

Thanks!
-jay"}, {'account_id': 1132, 'date': '2012-04-04 21:16:18.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

Jay:

Unfortunately routes doesn't automagically allow us to optionally support trailing slashes. So I would rather not require users to have a trailing slash when requesting /v1/ but require a user not to use a trailing slash with /v1/images. It's a very poor user experience. This is aligning everything not to expect trailing slashes."}, {'account_id': 1132, 'date': '2012-04-05 00:14:32.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

Unfortunately, there appears to be a bug in routes (or maybe our usage of it) that makes it so http://glance.example.com/v2 is unroutable :/ I've reverted dropping the trailing slash for now."}, {'account_id': 1132, 'date': '2012-04-05 00:14:35.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 2284, 'date': '2012-04-05 09:24:10.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: (2 inline comments)

commit_message:
Use glance config files from source tree

This rewrites the config files for Glance API and Registry (-paste.ini and .conf)
rather than use templates from devstack/files.

Fixes bug 950289

Change-Id: I90151e36bb5f778499481e9abe0d8637d41f19aa

Script to monitor available devstack node count.

* devstack-vm-threshold.py
  New script to print count of available nodes. The threshold is
  specified in command line. If available node count is less than
  threshold, the script exit with error code (1).

  The available node count is written to a file. File name is
  specified in command line. If file name is not specified, it is
  written to ~/vm-threshold.txt file.

  usage: devstack-vm-threshold.py [-h] -t threshold [-f stat-file]

commit_message:
Bug 929021.

Monitor ready node count for all providers.

* devstack-vm-threshold.py
New script to print count of available nodes, across all providers.
The threshold is specified in command line. If available node count
is less than threshold, the script exit with error code (1).

The available node count is written to a file. File name is
specified in command line. If file name is not specified, it is
written to ~/vm-threshold.txt file.

usage: devstack-vm-threshold.py [-h] -t threshold [-f stat-file]

Change-Id: Ib5d24b2a81a79c753ede4bc0c59e17808dc75b18

commit_message:
Add result tracking.

Add a new table to track the results of tests.  Include Success,
failure, timeout, elapsed time, job, gerrit change.  This will
let us collect statistics on the time certain jobs take to run
on certain images or providers, and whether false positives
are higher for some providers.

Change-Id: I7fde5e04ca4a08ecb76eea08cc930634087f7372

subject: Implement blueprint nova-sharedfs
messages:
[{'account_id': 1998, 'date': '2012-03-13 21:16:07.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

I'm not expecting this to be merged pre-Folsom, but I would appreciate comments in the meantime.

I'm especially interested in reactions to the notification-hooking method I use in sharedfs_notifier.py, as I have another up-and-coming extension that needs something similar."}, {'account_id': 1998, 'date': '2012-03-13 22:38:40.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 1998, 'date': '2012-03-21 19:58:52.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 679, 'date': '2012-03-22 20:45:11.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

(5 inline comments)

There are several problems in the shared_fs extension itself.  One is mostly stylistic, but the others are more serious.  Also, don't define tearDown() if you don't need to augment what the default tearDown() does; inheritance is a handy trick :)"}, {'account_id': 1998, 'date': '2012-03-22 22:03:33.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: (5 inline comments)

Thank you for the useful comments!'}, {'account_id': 1998, 'date': '2012-03-22 22:03:59.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 679, 'date': '2012-03-22 22:28:50.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

(5 inline comments)

We're getting closer.  You left in two instances of a do-nothing tearDown() method, though, and there are some typos in your switch-over to raising HTTP<blah> exceptions."}, {'account_id': 1998, 'date': '2012-03-22 22:51:38.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: (3 inline comments)

Thanks again... hope this next rev is at least a little less slapdash than the last.'}, {'account_id': 1998, 'date': '2012-03-22 22:53:58.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 5.'}, {'account_id': 1998, 'date': '2012-03-23 15:45:17.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 6.'}, {'account_id': 679, 'date': '2012-03-23 15:49:43.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

(1 inline comment)

'}, {'account_id': 100, 'date': '2012-03-23 16:19:48.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6: Do not submit

(15 inline comments)

A mix of minor nits, missing i18n and a couple of bugs that should be fixed first.'}, {'account_id': 1998, 'date': '2012-03-23 16:46:12.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 6: (13 inline comments)

Thanks for the close read, Johannes.  I'll resubmit in a moment."}, {'account_id': 1998, 'date': '2012-03-23 18:29:48.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 7.'}, {'account_id': 100, 'date': '2012-03-23 18:38:06.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7: (7 inline comments)

'}, {'account_id': 1998, 'date': '2012-03-23 19:17:32.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 8.'}, {'account_id': 100, 'date': '2012-03-23 19:31:00.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 8: (7 inline comments)

We're very close..."}, {'account_id': 1998, 'date': '2012-03-23 20:13:25.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8: (3 inline comments)

Thanks again'}, {'account_id': 1998, 'date': '2012-03-23 20:13:36.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 9.'}, {'account_id': 100, 'date': '2012-03-23 20:34:02.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 9: No score

No more review notes from me, but just checking on the procedure for unapproved blueprints.'}, {'account_id': 679, 'date': '2012-03-23 20:56:09.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 9: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

reviewers: [{'_account_id': 3, 'name': 'Jenkins', 'username': 'jenkins'}, {'_account_id': 490, 'name': 'Sumit Naiksatam', 'email': 'sumitnaiksatam@gmail.com', 'username': 'snaiksat'}, {'_account_id': 669, 'name': 'Rick Clark', 'email': 'rick@openstack.org', 'username': 'dendrobates'}, {'_account_id': 2245, 'name': 'Jacky Hu', 'email': 'hudayou@hotmail.com', 'username': 'hudayou'}, {'_account_id': 2350, 'name': 'Willian Molinari', 'email': 'pothix@pothix.com', 'username': 'pothix'}, {'_account_id': 2472, 'name': 'Doug Hellmann', 'email': 'dhellmann@redhat.com', 'username': 'doug-hellmann'}, {'_account_id': 2487, 'name': 'Thiago Morello', 'email': 'morellon@gmail.com', 'username': 'morellon'}]
messages:
[{'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-04-07 06:03:05.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Verified

Build Successful 
 
https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-quantum-merge/152/ : SUCCESS'}, {'account_id': 490, 'date': '2012-04-07 06:03:05.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

Changes to the Cisco README file have been submitted in a different commit. I would request you to remove that file from this patch. In general, when it comes to plugins, we have been following the convention of checking with the people who are more closely affiliated with that plugin, before making a change to that plugin (since it's quite likely that those people might have plans to do things in a specific way). A simple way to go about this is by proposing the plugin-specific change in the netstack list."}, {'account_id': 2245, 'date': '2012-04-07 06:03:05.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

git diff does not show you white spaces.

I use vim, you can search by using '/\s\+$' in vim
for the original file.

Then you'll see the white spaces highlighted."}, {'account_id': 2245, 'date': '2012-04-07 06:03:05.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

You can check the size of files also
and you'll notices the modified files gets smaller."}, {'account_id': 2245, 'date': '2012-04-07 06:03:05.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

I don't!"}, {'account_id': 2245, 'date': '2012-04-07 06:03:05.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Thanks.
I guess the default is unix.
Since all other files default to unix.
Do we need to have a variant default for the files here?'}, {'account_id': 2245, 'date': '2012-04-07 06:03:05.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Removed some trailing whitespaces from the following lines:
24,40,49 ...

Gerrit does not display it properly.

If you have time, you might report a bug to gerrit.'}, {'account_id': 2245, 'date': '2012-04-07 06:03:05.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

I'd like to know the answer also,
the size seems gets much smaller
than the size of trailing white spaces."}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-04-07 06:03:05.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Verified

Build Successful 
 
https://jenkins.openstack.org/job/gate-quantum-merge/220/ : SUCCESS'}, {'account_id': 2245, 'date': '2012-04-07 06:03:05.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 2350, 'date': '2012-04-07 06:03:05.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

I think that I found the reason...

Before:

$ file quantum/plugins/cisco/README 
quantum/plugins/cisco/README: ASCII English text, with CRLF line terminators

After:

$ file quantum/plugins/cisco/README 
quantum/plugins/cisco/README: ASCII English text

I prefer to use Unix line breaks but I don't know what is the openstack default, so I think you should not convert it for now."}, {'account_id': 2350, 'date': '2012-04-07 06:03:05.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

I don't think so, if the default is unix the code is right."}, {'account_id': 2350, 'date': '2012-04-07 06:03:05.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Just for the record, I understand what are you doing and I agree, trailing whitespaces are bad. I'm using `autocmd BufWritePre * :%s/\s\+$//e` on my .vimrc to remove it on each save.

I'm just trying to understand why the whole file looks modified on git. Do you understand why is this happening?"}, {'account_id': 2350, 'date': '2012-04-07 06:03:05.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: (1 inline comment)

'}, {'account_id': 2350, 'date': '2012-04-07 06:03:05.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Try this on a clean quantum repository:

git fetch https://review.openstack.org/p/openstack/quantum refs/changes/67/4867/1 && git checkout FETCH_HEAD

And then run `git log -p`'}, {'account_id': 2350, 'date': '2012-04-07 06:03:05.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

This is not a gerrit bug, I've downloaded the source and ran `git log -p` and the result is the same."}, {'account_id': 2350, 'date': '2012-04-07 06:03:05.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

add an option to disable color

If --openstack-color is set in a config, it's helpful to be able to turn
it back off from the command line.

Change-Id: I01654b4f892cb62722a74e2e40734c847b6f53ef

[{'created': '2012-04-04 16:56:19.000000000', 'message': "Use -1 end-to-end to represent unlimited quotas.

Dispense with the mapping of -1 to None for unlimited thresholds.

commit_message:
Use -1 end-to-end for unlimited quotas

Dispense with the mapping of -1 to None for unlimited quota and
quota-class thresholds.

Now -1 is persisted directly in the quotas table to represent unlimited.

Avoids the asymmetry of -1 representing unlimited on quotas create/update
versus None for quotas show.

Change-Id: Ic9d3e22c4d68447af6a7f79a9703fa6ac26f01cc

* logging.conf rewritten
* adds tools/set-ini.py for editing INI/conf files

We've hacked it until the bug is fixed.  See the FIXME in the code.

Partially fixes bug 944169

commit_message:
B) Use keystone config files from source; move to /etc/keystone

* Put all config files in /etc/keystone
* keystone.conf rewritten
* logging.conf.sample rewritten to logging.conf
* default_catalog.templates copied from devstack/files
* iniset() now properly adds options that do not previously exist

Fixed to re-configure the catalog templated backend; sql is the
default in trunk now but DevStack needs a bit more work before
it can use it.

Change-Id: Ic7060ef897e47495cd08ca3786e49fdebadf6723

I buy the patch, but I want to get the all-clear from the primary consumers of this functionality before we rip it out.'}, {'account_id': 209, 'date': '2012-03-29 15:13:27.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

My thoughts were that the consumers can keep this in a private branch until the authentication system is more pluggable.'}, {'account_id': 1132, 'date': '2012-03-29 15:25:29.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

That's a fine approach, I just want to make sure the proper parties have been notified, that's all :)"}, {'account_id': 927, 'date': '2012-03-29 15:33:03.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

subject: Introduce Cross-Origin Resource Sharing (CORS) support.
messages:
[{'account_id': 6, 'date': '2012-03-29 19:07:23.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

Hi Yoshiaki - 

thank you for the patch - I want to understand CORS a bit better to understand what this is enabling before I stamp any approval on it. I  understand your use case (thank you for updating the bug with that detail). I need to understand what options and what this implies. Off to read and research..."}, {'account_id': 2230, 'date': '2012-03-29 23:33:56.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

I appreciate the enthusiasm for adding CORS support to Keystone.

I can't agree that this patch introduces CORS support. This patch hard-codes a single CORS value. It provides no configurability, and no way to turn it off. The chosen default value is to disable an extremely important browser security feature.

I appreciate that this change makes it easier to support Javascript applications which utilize a public Keystone endpoint. Not all Openstack users are running public clouds. This patch makes private clouds significantly less secure.

For some help imagining why "Access-Control-Allow-Origin: *" is a bad default, I suggest starting with this document:
http://code.google.com/p/html5security/wiki/CrossOriginRequestSecurity

Furthermore, this feature should not be an integral part of Keystone. While it may make development life easier to add CORS support directly to Keystone, real public deployments will be behind Nginx or Apache. Both of these packages easily support the addition of CORS headers and responses. Furthermore, they support the fine-grained security controls this patch is lacking.

This patch cannot be added to Keystone as-is, and CORS is a feature Keystone itself should not implement. It is critical that we as the Openstack community recognize the strengths of the different components of our stack, and avoid wasted effort in duplicating features better supplied elsewhere.'}, {'account_id': 539, 'date': '2012-03-30 02:14:49.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Thanks for your comments - I appreciate your in depth discussion.  I
think your arguments are correct, yet I want to ask you some
questions.

First of all, is Keystone not meant to be exposed pubic by itself?
This looks quite weird to me because then why would you have a
documents running Keystone w/ SSL?  I'm asking this question because
we are really thinking to use this in production at some point.  So I
want to be clear how Keystone is supposed to be deployed.  If you
think Keystone must always be served with other web servers, then
please ignore the following question.

Assuming that Keystone could live with its own, do you still think
that proper CORS shound not be included in Keystone?  This also looks
weird because handling preflight requests with OPTIONS method have to
be tied to the application logic IIUC.  I don't expect the patch to go
in as is, yet I would prefer to handle CORS precisely by having these
discussions - making allow origin configurable, should the token be
treated as credentials in CORS specifications, more support on each
resource, etc.

What do you think?"}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2012-04-06 06:03:05.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Abandoned

code review expired after 1 week of no activity after a negative review'}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2012-04-06 06:03:05.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

code review expired after 1 week of no activity after a negative review'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2012-03-29 02:27:40.000000000', 'message': 'Introduce Cross-Origin Resource Sharing (CORS) support.

This patch adds the Cross-Origin Request Sharing (CORS) support to
Keystone.  I implemented by referring to the specification below.

http://www.w3.org/TR/cors/

In detail, "Access-Control-Allow-Origin" is added to the default
header.  Also to comply preflight requests, I added "OPTIONS" method
hander to "/v2.0/tokens" which returns a response with
"Access-Control-Allow-Headers" and "Access-Control-Allow-Methods".
Tests that check these headers are also added.

This fixes Bug #967926

Change-Id: I04addef21ec58d92e527824652d44f08c5de25d7
'}]
commit_message:
Introduce Cross-Origin Resource Sharing (CORS) support.

This patch adds the Cross-Origin Request Sharing (CORS) support to
Keystone.  I implemented by referring to the specification below.

http://www.w3.org/TR/cors/

In detail, "Access-Control-Allow-Origin" is added to the default
header.  Also to comply preflight requests, I added "OPTIONS" method
hander to "/v2.0/tokens" which returns a response with
"Access-Control-Allow-Headers" and "Access-Control-Allow-Methods".
Tests that check these headers are also added.

This fixes Bug #967926

Change-Id: I04addef21ec58d92e527824652d44f08c5de25d7

commit_message:
Add support for Fedora 16

Highlights:
* Add GetOSInfo, package_install, yum_install to functions
* Add files/rpms/*
* get_packages() only loads deps for services that are enabled
* begin moving log files to /opt/stack/logs
  * Apache logs moved, working with SELinux thanks to rbryant@redhat.com

23Feb2012
    SELinux, horizon deps, cloudfiles version
27Feb2012
    More SELinux, tgt
06Mar2012
    Rebase, apache logs
13Mar2012
    Rebase, sudo, apache logs redux
16Mar2012
    Rebase, apache log tail
21Mar2012
    Rebase, memcached; sudo and nova-rootwrap from russellb

Change-Id: I059ae1c0676ed6da805a8dc6bae7565ab6f61c71

(9 inline comments)

Hi Chris! Great start!

Some inline comments to address, but overall, looking good. Thanks much!

-jay"}, {'account_id': 2439, 'date': '2012-03-13 21:04:13.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 2439, 'date': '2012-03-13 21:06:23.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 5.'}, {'account_id': 2439, 'date': '2012-03-13 21:09:37.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 6.'}, {'account_id': 7, 'date': '2012-03-14 18:16:41.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 6: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

(3 inline comments)

Hi Chris, hang in there! See inline notes...

Also, I'm getting an SSL handshake error when running this branch. Still trying to figure out what change results in the failure...

See http://paste.openstack.org/show/9385/"}, {'account_id': 2439, 'date': '2012-03-14 18:27:28.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6:

Jay, are you trying to use ssl? If not, check your tempest.conf, make sure use_ssl=false vs use_ssl=False (which will be true) https://bugs.launchpad.net/tempest/+bug/945850'}, {'account_id': 7, 'date': '2012-03-14 18:34:11.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6:

Chris, the SSL problems went away after rebasing your branch against master.

However, when running the identity.test_roles test, I get this now:

jpipes@uberbox:~/repos/tempest$ nosetests -sxv tempest.tests.identity.test_roles
======================================================================
ERROR: test suite for <class 'tempest.tests.identity.test_roles.RolesTest'>
----------------------------------------------------------------------
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/usr/lib/pymodules/python2.7/nose/suite.py", line 208, in run
    self.setUp()
  File "/usr/lib/pymodules/python2.7/nose/suite.py", line 291, in setUp
    self.setupContext(ancestor)
  File "/usr/lib/pymodules/python2.7/nose/suite.py", line 314, in setupContext
    try_run(context, names)
  File "/usr/lib/pymodules/python2.7/nose/util.py", line 478, in try_run
    return func()
  File "/home/jpipes/repos/tempest/tempest/tests/identity/test_roles.py", line 16, in setUpClass
AttributeError: 'Manager' object has no attribute 'keystone_v2_client'

----------------------------------------------------------------------
Ran 0 tests in 0.396s

FAILED (errors=1)'}, {'account_id': 7, 'date': '2012-03-14 18:37:06.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 6:

Chris, disregard my last comment about the missing keystone_v2_client... I hadn't completed my rebase."}, {'account_id': 2439, 'date': '2012-03-14 19:08:40.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 7.'}, {'account_id': 7, 'date': '2012-03-14 19:14:07.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7:

ok, pulling again to retest.'}, {'account_id': 7, 'date': '2012-03-14 19:16:27.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7:

Chris, you need to rebase against master still.

Make sure you do:

 git checkout master && git pull
 git checkout <THIS_TOPIC_BRANCH>
 git rebase master
 # Fix up all merge conflicts and for each file
 # you change, remember to git add <FILE>
 git rebase --continue
 git review'}, {'account_id': 2439, 'date': '2012-03-14 19:37:47.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 8.'}, {'account_id': 7, 'date': '2012-03-22 16:20:21.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8:

Pulling locally now for testing... sorry for the delay Chris.'}, {'account_id': 7, 'date': '2012-03-22 16:35:59.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 8: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

Chris, I believe that you need to modify the rest_client checks for the KS-ADM extension to better deal with /v2.0/ already being part of the auth URL. I'm seeing a bunch of these when I run the suite:

 tempest.common.rest_client: ERROR: Request URL: http://192.168.1.98:5000/v2.0/v2.0/OS-KSADM/roles

And my conf looks like this:

jpipes@uberbox:~/repos/tempest$ cat etc/tempest.conf
 [identity]
 use_ssl=False
 host=192.168.1.98
 port=5000
 api_version=v2.0
 path=tokens
 user=demo
 password=pass
 tenant_name=demo
 strategy=keystone"}, {'account_id': 2439, 'date': '2012-03-23 00:10:37.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 9.'}, {'account_id': 7, 'date': '2012-04-03 19:31:46.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 9: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

Chris, I'm getting a bunch of errors when running this branch....

http://paste.openstack.org/show/12390/

-jay"}, {'account_id': 2439, 'date': '2012-04-05 20:44:53.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 9: Abandoned

This patch set is old. I will resubmit after changes to Manager, discussed in lp#973338 are in.'}]

commit_message:
Adds keystone admin client and tests for keystone roles.

Keystone admin client and new section in config for
[identity-admin] as suggested by Jay Pipes

Adds a config enhancement for catalog_type to support
using the adminURL vs publicURL

Fixes bug 902389

Change-Id: I60d50142293303a48e3d36cb9375ccbc117ca4c8

commit_message:
Get tempest configuration file up2date with trunk

The old configure_tempest script wasn't writing an
appropriate Tempest config file. This should get things
updated to the point where Tempest should at least run
properly without erroring out on configuration issues like
we've been seeing...

Change-Id: Ice7aca10e74c0a365e1638f7b3e423aa768d3074

commit_message:
Change the compute_port to Nova's default of 8774.

This was causing unit tests to fail in Keystone. 3000 != 8774.

Change-Id: I804ac62a6022f2759eb889d34d006a61f625a296

Added descriptions of URI parameters and request body attributes to all API operations.
Patch set #2 removes the *.bak file.
Patch set #3 adds link to PDF.
Patch set #4 removed xmlns descriptions
Patch set #5 revised description of imageRef and flavorRef
Change-Id: Ic84cf690f5599e488aaec77166ec16b0fb1ac094

subject: Fixes lp:973338 Moved admin user properties from compute-admin section to compute in config.py Edited tempest.conf.sample
messages:
[{'account_id': 7, 'date': '2012-04-04 16:13:15.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Rohit, see my comment on the bug report... I want to discuss this before moving much further in this direction, but I acknowledge the bug is real...'}, {'account_id': 1073, 'date': '2012-04-04 16:41:46.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Hi Jay,

The compute-admin section and ComputeAdminConfig makes sense to me now. I think I'll add the ComputeAdminConfig in the next patch set and withdraw my proposed changes around conf.
However, I still would like to discuss an effective solution for the Manager class.

Thanks,
Rohit"}, {'account_id': 1073, 'date': '2012-04-04 17:06:20.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Ah, we could have separate *_admin_clients added to the client list in Manager(),  for those api tests that only run as admin users (like create and delete flavors).
Set these user credentials and the corresponding admin clients in Manager. Then I would not require two Manager objects, for admin and non-admin users.'}, {'account_id': 97, 'date': '2012-04-05 06:20:59.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Especially given the events of last week, I'd like to hold off until we can discuss this in real time together. For my two cents, I've always envisioned the top level Manager class as a single user entity, and one would create multiple managers for different users."}, {'account_id': 1073, 'date': '2012-04-05 06:52:12.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Daryl, 
I'd prefer if we could get an acceptable solution to this, sooner, even if temporary. With the current behavior, I don't think we can leverage the [compute-admin] section in tempest.conf to create manager objects for admins. 
We have a bunch of tests to check in that need this functionality. 
Declaring admin_clients for admin users in the Manager class might be a good stop gap as per me."}, {'account_id': 1073, 'date': '2012-04-05 07:03:04.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Yet, it still needs further discussion :)'}, {'account_id': 97, 'date': '2012-04-05 14:51:15.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Rohit, I agree. However, no matter how necessary this is (which I agree), in the last few weeks we've had issues due to too rapidly making decisions. We need to be patient and make sure the changes we make satisfy everyone."}, {'account_id': 1073, 'date': '2012-04-05 15:10:11.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Sure, I understand, let's get a consensus :)"}, {'account_id': 1073, 'date': '2012-04-05 18:01:26.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Abandoned

Pulling this back to give way to new changes to Manager() and keep the config re-factorings.'}]

commit_message:
Fix bug 957618, remove nova-manage image

* Minor markup changes as well to remove <literallayout >
* Should pick up more changed to "creating custom images" from CSS OSS team after 12.04 Ubuntu is released this month
* Fix bug 969598, show more endpoint creation examples
* Fix bug 968679, fix example, provide info about ports for each service
* Fix bug 965868, improve text about URL values for endpoints and services

Change-Id: Iab3c905f35b1c158e6d924ac8cf41c87e59d123c

commit_message:
Cleanup _make_plugin_call()

Not all calls to plugins need a path argument, so make it optional.
Fix TODO to use _make_agent_call() again. Use 'instance' instead of
'vm' to make it clearer what kind of object it is.

Change-Id: I279317cd07a5753b6c8dd686d2b4786ff24b66df

commit_message:
Push id generation into _make_agent_call()

None of the callers use the id generated for any purpose other than
passing to _make_agent_call(), so just have _make_agent_call()
generate it for the caller

Change-Id: I5bd4392d2666dcb609891f3017fb9eb0d8c243ad

subject: Don't crash with a bad Content-MD5.
messages: [{'account_id': 1026, 'date': '2012-04-05 02:54:04.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't submit this Thanks. The error code looks wrong? I got the following from aws: InvalidDigestThe Content-MD5 you specified was invalid. Also why x-amz-storage-class header is necessary in the unit test code?"}, {'account_id': 866, 'date': '2012-04-05 12:55:18.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Thanks! I am doing quite a bit of changes to swift3 to fix those errors : https://bugs.launchpad.net/swift/+bug/973516 (test suite from ceph) I am thinking to do that in github as this will be easier before making a big merge request to gerrit. https://github.com/chmouel/swift/tree/swift3_bugfixes Let me know if you would like to contribute.'}, {'account_id': 1026, 'date': '2012-04-05 14:38:10.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Why a big merge request? It's too difficult for other developers to review such. Creating lots of bug reports and submitting a fix for each should be fine. With that way, developers could share the work easily too."}, {'account_id': 866, 'date': '2012-04-05 15:08:35.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: The resources for the swift team to review patches is sparse so having to wait that patch get merged everytime (and rebase if there is changes between the list of patches) is difficult.'}, {'account_id': 1026, 'date': '2012-04-05 15:38:57.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I don't think that it's so difficult. Also surely it's difficult to review a big patch to fixes multiple bugs."}, {'account_id': 866, 'date': '2012-04-05 16:43:26.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Abandoned'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2012-04-04 20:06:35.000000000', 'message': "Don't crash with a bad Content-MD5.

- Exit with an InvalidDigest when we have a bad Content-MD5.
- Fixes bug 973710.

Change-Id: I5344dd862e2f0f9358d3f31400a9ac14011c53a2
"}]
commit_message:
Don't crash with a bad Content-MD5.

- Exit with an InvalidDigest when we have a bad Content-MD5.
- Fixes bug 973710.

Change-Id: I5344dd862e2f0f9358d3f31400a9ac14011c53a2

commit_message:
Fixed bug 962840, added a test case.

eventlet.tpool.Proxy doesn't work with old-style class in __str__()
or __repr__() calls. See bug #962840 for details.
We perform a monkey patch to replace those two instance methods.

Change-Id: Ia51bbd3e71cad7df45da5b3b27eef70f9d9e9002

reviewers: [{'_account_id': 335, 'name': 'Paul Voccio', 'email': 'paul@substation9.com', 'username': 'pvo'}, {'_account_id': 360, 'name': 'Dan Prince', 'email': 'dprince@redhat.com', 'username': 'dan-prince'}, {'_account_id': 679, 'name': 'Kevin L. Mitchell', 'email': 'klmitch@mit.edu', 'username': 'klmitch'}, {'_account_id': 2166, 'name': 'SmokeStack CI', 'username': 'smokestack', 'tags': ['SERVICE_USER']}, {'_account_id': 2284, 'name': 'Eoghan Glynn', 'email': 'eglynn@redhat.com', 'username': 'eglynn'}]
messages:
[{'account_id': 2284, 'date': '2012-04-04 13:20:26.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

(1 inline comment)

One question and a suggestion inline.

Cheers,
Eoghan"}, {'account_id': 2284, 'date': '2012-04-04 13:44:26.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: (1 inline comment)

'}, {'account_id': 360, 'date': '2012-04-04 13:53:11.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 360, 'date': '2012-04-04 13:54:22.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

Eoghan:

I removed that bit of unnecessary code. The unit tests confirm we don't need it. Nice catch."}, {'account_id': 335, 'date': '2012-04-04 14:18:17.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

'}, {'account_id': 335, 'date': '2012-04-04 14:19:21.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: No score

Looks like the other merged'}, {'account_id': 2284, 'date': '2012-04-04 14:34:50.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

Would it be more symmetric to use -1 end-to-end to represent unlimited? (instead of -1 for create/update, but None for show)

So -1 would be stored as the hard_limit in the quotas & quota_classes tables to represent an unlimited threshold, and the checks against None in nova/quota.py would morph to == -1.

Then novaclient could also be updated to report say '-1 (unlimited)' instead of None for unlimited thresholds.

This would impact the corresponding change to the project-specific quotas also:

  https://github.com/openstack/nova/commit/7f226a7b"}, {'account_id': 360, 'date': '2012-04-04 15:04:34.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

Eoghan,

I think I'm Okay with that... it will however require a database migration too which makes it a bit more risky for Essex perhaps. Not sure. Let talk about it on IRC.

In the meantime making quota classes match what we do for flags seems to make sense. (and makes Kevin happy too)"}, {'account_id': 360, 'date': '2012-04-04 15:06:55.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 679, 'date': '2012-04-04 15:20:17.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

'}, {'account_id': 2284, 'date': '2012-04-05 12:01:19.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

If we go with -1 end-to-end to represent unlimited, then this patch would be superceeded by:

  https://review.openstack.org/6266'}, {'account_id': 360, 'date': '2012-04-05 12:53:16.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

eglynn:

I actually like using -1's in the DB too. I wasn't sure if we would do that for Folsom.... but perhaps backport this patch to Essex.

If we aren't planning on backporting either then I'll abandone this and we can just go with the -1's in the DB.

Thanks."}, {'account_id': 360, 'date': '2012-04-05 13:01:45.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: Abandoned

Quota classes aren't much use in Essex anyway. I'm abandon this unless someone objects....

For Folsom + we can hopefully standardize our -1/unlimited flag usage."}]

subject: added expiry to chexor in object replicator
messages:
[{'account_id': 2282, 'date': '2012-04-03 19:37:31.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

'}, {'account_id': 2282, 'date': '2012-04-03 19:39:44.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Looks good enough for me: unless you want to sacrifice performances checking if something does exist is not easy.'}, {'account_id': 2828, 'date': '2012-04-03 22:36:56.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

Using mtime of the hashes file seems like a poor choice to make a hash refresh decision, since it can be modified by the object server, replicator or auditor, with no real bearing on how out-of-date the hashes are.

I think to do it right, you'd need to track last-refresh time per suffix dir in the hashes metadata and use that to expire them.

I don't know what a good default timeout would be, but it'd have to be much larger than 24 hours.  Maybe more like 60 days.  Doing a complete directory traversal on a dense storage node can take months."}, {'account_id': 330, 'date': '2012-04-04 00:27:57.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 2828, 'date': '2012-04-04 00:47:55.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

It can't possibly re-hash the entire directory structure every 24 hours."}, {'account_id': 330, 'date': '2012-04-04 03:03:58.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 1216, 'date': '2012-04-04 23:10:04.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

As discussed in IRC, this is probably better implemented by the ZBF auditor scan recomputing the hashes.pkl for a partition just after it finishes scanning a partition. Also, this has nothing to do with chexor."}, {'account_id': 330, 'date': '2012-04-04 23:15:49.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Abandoned'}]

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-04-04 20:45:57.000000000', 'message': 'Make the publishing location a maven parameter.

The Jenkins jobs will be changed so that they are triggered by gerrit
ref-updated events, which provide information about the branch that has
just been updated.  We'll run a script at the beginning of the job that
determines where the content should be published based on the branch
(trunk, diablo, etc), and then pass that as a paremeter to the maven
build job.

The default is set to "unknown" so that an accidental build without
the parameter set will not overwrite something important (like trunk).

Jobs for books that are not yet core projects should manually set the
value to 'incubated', ignoring the value from the script:

 mvn -Drelease.path.name=incubated ...

Change-Id: I93f195f2bd1a73414a3995c0aff5835aae6501d6
'}, {'created': '2012-04-04 21:53:50.000000000', 'message': 'Make the publishing location a maven parameter.

The Jenkins jobs will be changed so that they are triggered by gerrit
ref-updated events, which provide information about the branch that has
just been updated.  We'll run a script at the beginning of the job that
determines where the content should be published based on the branch
(trunk, diablo, etc), and then pass that as a paremeter to the maven
build job.

The default is set to "unknown" so that an accidental build without
the parameter set will not overwrite something important (like trunk).

Jobs for books that are not yet core projects should manually set the
value to 'incubated', ignoring the value from the script:

 mvn -Drelease.path.name=incubated ...

comments.enabled is also added as a parameter to be set similarly.

Change-Id: I93f195f2bd1a73414a3995c0aff5835aae6501d6
'}]
commit_message:
Make the publishing location a maven parameter.

The Jenkins jobs will be changed so that they are triggered by gerrit
ref-updated events, which provide information about the branch that has
just been updated.  We'll run a script at the beginning of the job that
determines where the content should be published based on the branch
(trunk, diablo, etc), and then pass that as a paremeter to the maven
build job.

The default is set to "unknown" so that an accidental build without
the parameter set will not overwrite something important (like trunk).

Jobs for books that are not yet core projects should manually set the
value to 'incubated', ignoring the value from the script:

 mvn -Drelease.path.name=incubated ...

comments.enabled is also added as a parameter to be set similarly.

Change-Id: I93f195f2bd1a73414a3995c0aff5835aae6501d6

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-04-04 15:50:16.000000000', 'message': 'Add generic PasteDeploy app and filter factories

These generic factories allow us to dump copied and pasted
app_factory and filter_factory methods.

The main difference is the paste configuration changes from:

  [app:myapp]
  paste.app_factory = myapp:app_factory
  ...
  [filter:myfilter]
  paste.filter_factory = myapp:filter_factory

to this:

  [app:myapp]
  paste.app_factory = openstack.common.pastedeploy:app_factory
  openstack.app_factory = myapp:App
  ...
  [filter:myfilter]
  paste.filter_factory = openstack.common.pastedeploy:filter_factory
  openstack.filter_factory = myapp:Filter

Apart from reducing code duplication, this will also allow us to have
the generic factories inject other data into the apps and filters.

This could implemented as a new feature in PasteDeploy itself - e.g.
allow the loadapp() caller supply a python object which is passed on
to the factories.

In the meantime, Glance has code like this to pass a ConfigOpts instance
to factories. Keystone is moving a similar way, as will other projects
as they move away from a global config object.

Change-Id: I928d1f6da154f0f41edd624e25b8918a0e12cb28
'}, {'created': '2012-04-04 15:50:16.000000000', 'message': 'Add generic PasteDeploy app and filter factories

These generic factories allow us to dump copied and pasted
app_factory and filter_factory methods.

The main difference is the paste configuration changes from:

  [app:myapp]
  paste.app_factory = myapp:app_factory
  ...
  [filter:myfilter]
  paste.filter_factory = myapp:filter_factory

to this:

  [app:myapp]
  paste.app_factory = openstack.common.pastedeploy:app_factory
  openstack.app_factory = myapp:App
  ...
  [filter:myfilter]
  paste.filter_factory = openstack.common.pastedeploy:filter_factory
  openstack.filter_factory = myapp:Filter

Apart from reducing code duplication, this will also allow us to have
the generic factories inject other data into the apps and filters.

This could implemented as a new feature in PasteDeploy itself - e.g.
allow the loadapp() caller supply a python object which is passed on
to the factories.

In the meantime, Glance has code like this to pass a ConfigOpts instance
to factories. Keystone is moving a similar way, as will other projects
as they move away from a global config object.

Change-Id: I928d1f6da154f0f41edd624e25b8918a0e12cb28
'}]
commit_message:
Add generic PasteDeploy app and filter factories

These generic factories allow us to dump copied and pasted
app_factory and filter_factory methods.

The main difference is the paste configuration changes from:

  [app:myapp]
  paste.app_factory = myapp:app_factory
  ...
  [filter:myfilter]
  paste.filter_factory = myapp:filter_factory

to this:

  [app:myapp]
  paste.app_factory = openstack.common.pastedeploy:app_factory
  openstack.app_factory = myapp:App
  ...
  [filter:myfilter]
  paste.filter_factory = openstack.common.pastedeploy:filter_factory
  openstack.filter_factory = myapp:Filter

Apart from reducing code duplication, this will also allow us to have
the generic factories inject other data into the apps and filters.

This could implemented as a new feature in PasteDeploy itself - e.g.
allow the loadapp() caller supply a python object which is passed on
to the factories.

In the meantime, Glance has code like this to pass a ConfigOpts instance
to factories. Keystone is moving a similar way, as will other projects
as they move away from a global config object.

Change-Id: I928d1f6da154f0f41edd624e25b8918a0e12cb28

subject: Removed HACKING in favor of openstack-common
messages:
[{'account_id': 693, 'date': '2012-03-22 21:35:23.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

I don't think there's any justification for removing this file. Code standards should tend toward consistency across projects, but that isn't the case now and won't be in the visible future (swift is wildly out of compliance with the nova standard and vice-versa for instance).

Also, the wiki is the wrong place for this (or similar) document to reside. The ability to edit on the wiki is either wholly open to anyone on the OpenStack team on Launchpad, or it's locked down to administrators. Which means it can be modified at will by anyone without discussion, or it's locked to a handful of "special" users. Keeping the standard with the canonical representation of developer intent (namely the code) means that it can be modified by the existing standards we have for modifying the code itself and forces a discussion should someone desire to modify it.'}, {'account_id': 4, 'date': '2012-03-27 19:03:23.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Do not submit

Agree that the wiki is not an appropriate solution; I don't think we have (and think we need) a community consensus on this type of change."}, {'account_id': 4, 'date': '2012-03-27 19:45:30.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Also see https://review.openstack.org/#change,5708'}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2012-04-04 06:03:05.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

code review expired after 1 week of no activity after a negative review'}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2012-04-04 06:03:05.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Abandoned

code review expired after 1 week of no activity after a negative review'}]

commit_message:
Rename etc/keystone.conf to etc/keystone.conf.sample

Changes made to the distributed sample file overwrite local changes.
Moving config files to e.g. /etc/keystone doesn't work as
etc/keystone.conf is checked first.

Fixes bug 966670

Change-Id: Ia675d0e40e944e2b8a2f516dd4b39fc74706b2c1

subject: Unable to obtain admin token make message more meaningful when service admin password is broken.
messages:
[{'account_id': 6, 'date': '2012-03-27 00:53:18.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

'}, {'account_id': 2874, 'date': '2012-03-27 01:22:47.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 4, 'date': '2012-03-27 19:00:56.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

(4 inline comments)

"}, {'account_id': 2874, 'date': '2012-03-27 22:20:57.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

There are three bugs related to it:
https://bugs.launchpad.net/nova/+bug/965826
https://code.launchpad.net/bugs/962461
and 
https://code.launchpad.net/bugs/962454

Please help.'}, {'account_id': 6, 'date': '2012-03-27 22:31:21.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

(1 inline comment)

gongysh - I think I understand what you're trying to do (make debugging of configuration errors better), but responding to the API endpoint with details of the failure isn't the right way to do it. That's exposing the underbelly that should be hidden to the average user, but which *should* be available to the sysadmin running the service.

Change this to logging the errors with more detail, and you'll cover what I think you're after."}, {'account_id': 6, 'date': '2012-03-27 22:32:20.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

Additionally, the errors in the bugs you cited need to be fixed in python-novaclient, not in keystone's response."}, {'account_id': 2874, 'date': '2012-03-27 22:49:45.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

But 
503 Service Unavailable

'The server is currently unavailable. Please try again at a later time.'
How the user to do deal with it?  

In addition, the way of throwing error is not fridendly for novacient to deal with (keystoneclient also adopt the same way). At least we should output:
{u'error': {u'message': u'The server is currently unavailable. Please try again at a later time.'}}
Http code and title will be in http response header.

and again: 
Do you think 503 Service Unavailable is friendly to end user? Is it enough for they to report problem to administrator?"}, {'account_id': 6, 'date': '2012-03-27 22:55:22.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

The user can't do anything about it - it's a configuration mishap that only a sysadmin running the service can properly resolve. In short, there's nothing actionable for a user here.

I'm fine with wanting to build up better error responses from systems to clients, but let's arrange and do that consistently as client updates across OpenStack."}, {'account_id': 2874, 'date': '2012-03-27 23:03:54.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

and then what to do about those three bugs?'}, {'account_id': 2874, 'date': '2012-03-27 23:51:56.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: (3 inline comments)

'}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2012-04-04 06:03:04.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Abandoned

code review expired after 1 week of no activity after a negative review'}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2012-04-04 06:03:04.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

code review expired after 1 week of no activity after a negative review'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2012-03-26 06:31:40.000000000', 'message': "make message more meaningful when service admin password is broken.

old message is:
503 Service Unavailable

'The server is currently unavailable. Please try again at a later time.'
new message is:
503 Service Unavailable

Unable to obtain admin token

Bug #962461

Change-Id: I7a3a093b3cf50e3514ebadae76f79eeed7fcaf5b
"}, {'created': '2012-03-27 01:22:47.000000000', 'message': "Unable to obtain admin token
make message more meaningful when service admin password is broken.

old message is:
503 Service Unavailable

'The server is currently unavailable. Please try again at a later time.'
new message is:
HTTP/1.1 401 Unauthorized
{u'error': {u'message': u'Unable to obtain admin token'}}
Bug #962461

Change-Id: I7a3a093b3cf50e3514ebadae76f79eeed7fcaf5b
"}]
commit_message:
Unable to obtain admin token
make message more meaningful when service admin password is broken.

old message is:
503 Service Unavailable

'The server is currently unavailable. Please try again at a later time.'
new message is:
HTTP/1.1 401 Unauthorized
{u'error': {u'message': u'Unable to obtain admin token'}}
Bug #962461

Change-Id: I7a3a093b3cf50e3514ebadae76f79eeed7fcaf5b

Treat -1 quotas as unlimited.

Updates quota db API calls so they treat -1 quotas as unlimited
for consistency with the Nova flags.

Fixes LP Bug #972034.

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-04-04 02:13:12.000000000', 'message': "Add greenthread local storage model from nova

Thread local storage is obviously a very useful facility to have
available.

Nova has a very simple API for this which uses eventlet's corolocal
module and weakrefs. This looks to be generally useful and complete,
so let's pull it into openstack-common.

Change-Id: I52a08124297c9cb79def447436859bd8d2c0b622
"}]
commit_message:
Add greenthread local storage model from nova

Thread local storage is obviously a very useful facility to have
available.

Nova has a very simple API for this which uses eventlet's corolocal
module and weakrefs. This looks to be generally useful and complete,
so let's pull it into openstack-common.

Change-Id: I52a08124297c9cb79def447436859bd8d2c0b622

'}]
commit_message:
Allow unprivileged RADOS users to access rbd volumes.

This makes it possible to access rbd volumes with RADOS users with
restricted privileges. Previously, the admin user was always used.

This requires libvirt 0.9.8 or higher.

Change-Id: Ia4665c2a93a58a1c1290f467a3d9cd6cd22d7bd5

Fixes bug 971939

Fixes a few things.  If instance went to error, we should set the
migration to error so we don't retry.  Also, if we get any other
exceptions when trying to confirm resizes, we should not bail out of the
loop.  Also: be nice to other greenthreads and yield on each iteration.

Includes complete unit test for xenapi poll_unconfirmed_resizes which
didn't exist prior to this patch.

exceptions when trying to confirm resizes, we should not bail out of the

Change-Id: I6f7c1ccfd4be0f1497727d817130a821902d134d

commit_message:
Auto-confirming resizes would bail on exceptions

Fixes bug 971939

Fixes a few things.  If instance went to error, we should set the
migration to error so we don't retry.  Also, if we get any other
exceptions when trying to confirm resizes, we should not bail out of the
loop.  Also: be nice to other greenthreads and yield on each iteration.

Includes complete unit test for xenapi poll_unconfirmed_resizes which
didn't exist prior to this patch.

Change-Id: I6f7c1ccfd4be0f1497727d817130a821902d134d

commit_message:
Make import_nova_auth only create roles which don't already exist

Fixes bug #969088

If a role already exists, there's no particular need for import_nova_auth
to barf. Instead, we should just use the existing role.

Change-Id: I18ae38af62b4c2b2423e20e436611fc30f844ae1

commit_message:
Switch keystone.test.TestCase to use unittest2

 * unittest2 is already a test dependency, and has a large
   number of improvements over unittest.  The switch suggested
   removing TestCase assertions that already existed in unittest2's
   version and updating all subclasses to use the unittest2
   equivalents.

Change-Id: I024134ae7cade3b4951c7508c1ea50070762720f

commit_message:
Defaulted amazon disk & container formats

Fixes bug 972014

Default unset disk/container format to the corresponding container/disk
format, where the latter is an amazon format requiring a strict match.

Change-Id: I147df146940a21c368e95901343f36e1e3b7495b

commit_message:
Add support to swift_auth for tokenless authz

 * Updates keystone.middleware.swift_auth to allow token-less
   (unauthenticated) access for container sync (bug 954030) and
   permitted referrers (bug 924578).

commit_message:
ensure atomic manipulation of libvirt disk images

This pattern could probably be used elsewhere,
but only libvirt disk images are considered for now.
This change ensures there are no stale files left
anywhere in the path from glance, through the libvirt image cache.
These could cause subsequent operational errors either
directly or indirectly through disk wastage.

* nova/utils.py: Add a new remove_path_on_error() context manager
that is used to remove the passed PATH on a raised exception.
* nova/virt/images.py: Ensure temporary downloaded and
converted images are protected.
* nova/virt/libvirt/connection.py: Ensure all the images in
the image cache and instance dirs are protected.

Change-Id: I81a5407665a6998128c0dee41387ef00ebddeb4d

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-04-03 16:05:47.000000000', 'message': "Add MySQLPingListener() back

The use of wrap_db() to catch low-level problems in the connection
pool appears to be incompatible with new versions of sqlalchemy
(0.7.4/precise).  This re-instates the use of a event listener to
catch the error of 'mysql has gone away'.  Keeps the wrapping
logic in place for use before the connection pool has been constructed,
specifically to allow glance to retry its initial database connection on
service startup.

Fixes bug 967887

Change-Id: Ia732377d3404104b8acf7fe4ada164ec7ecf705f
"}]
commit_message:
Add MySQLPingListener() back

The use of wrap_db() to catch low-level problems in the connection
pool appears to be incompatible with new versions of sqlalchemy
(0.7.4/precise).  This re-instates the use of a event listener to
catch the error of 'mysql has gone away'.  Keeps the wrapping
logic in place for use before the connection pool has been constructed,
specifically to allow glance to retry its initial database connection on
service startup.

Fixes bug 967887

Change-Id: Ia732377d3404104b8acf7fe4ada164ec7ecf705f

commit_message:
Compile BigInteger to INTEGER for sqlite

Fixes bug 966243

Ensure BigInteger does not map to BIGINT for an auto-created
sqlite registry DB, as this type is not supported by sqlite.

Change-Id: I61f44fbe50ea406d2d593f8f53cab5da3af2222a

commit_message:
Add support to swift_auth for tokenless authz

 * Updates keystone.middleware.swift_auth to allow token-less
   (unauthenticated) access for container sync (bug 954030) and
   permitted referrers (bug 924578).

Change-Id: Ieccf458c44dfe55f546dc15c79704800dad59ac0

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-04-03 16:05:17.000000000', 'message': "Run version_control after auto-creating the DB

Fixes bug #966241

Currently, we auto-create an unversioned DB. This makes it awkward to
later upgrade it, especially since our 'glance-manage version_control'
command doesn't support retroactively versiioning it.

This is easily avoided by running version_control() after creating the
DB.

Change-Id: I935c06fcbcd3611c65d464850ca05445129f905f
"}]
commit_message:
Run version_control after auto-creating the DB

Fixes bug #966241

Currently, we auto-create an unversioned DB. This makes it awkward to
later upgrade it, especially since our 'glance-manage version_control'
command doesn't support retroactively versiioning it.

This is easily avoided by running version_control() after creating the
DB.

Change-Id: I935c06fcbcd3611c65d464850ca05445129f905f

commit_message:
rename the right index

fixes bug 953159
This did not affect sqlite and mysql, because those can not rename indexes
and thus used a separate sql file to drop and create the right one.

Change-Id: Iab80a65464a591b732ecce4c00d04df50624e912

commit_message:
Improve swift_auth test coverage + Minor fixes

 * Isolates authorize() tests from wsgi tests
 * Adds coverage for authorize()
 * Adds support for a blank reseller_prefix
 * Adds swift_auth test dependencies to tools/test-requires
 * Cleans up authorize()'s use of tenant_id/tenant_name
   (addresses bug 963546)

Change-Id: I603b89ab4fe8559b0f5d72528afd659ee0f0bce1

commit_message:
Add a generic tox build environment.

Allow for the running of arbitrary commands inside of a venv
so that we don't have to make tox envs for every blessed thing we want to
do.

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-04-03 13:05:34.000000000', 'message': 'Update tox.ini for jenkins.

The tox documentation is wrong, it looks for [tox:jenkins] instead
of [tox:hudson].  Also, run "pip freeze" before running tests from
within the virtualenv so we have a record of all versions used
in each test run in Jenkins.

Change-Id: Id0f34247f4545268f21dacb860d2e0fe72677a11
'}]
commit_message:
Update tox.ini for jenkins.

The tox documentation is wrong, it looks for [tox:jenkins] instead
of [tox:hudson].  Also, run "pip freeze" before running tests from
within the virtualenv so we have a record of all versions used
in each test run in Jenkins.

Change-Id: Id0f34247f4545268f21dacb860d2e0fe72677a11

commit_message:
Fix typo in tox.ini.

My last commit message was right, the code was wrong.  It's tox:jenkins.
Commands are invalid in tox: sections, so we'll get pip freeze run
another way.

Change-Id: Iafa21ff47cf5e3d8f57676be93e2fa6a0d0ab9b4

subject: Allow configurable handoff node constraints
messages:
[{'account_id': 330, 'date': '2012-03-26 09:21:53.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

This looks like a really interesting feature that could be especially useful for smaller swift clusters. However, I think it needs some (minor) changes before it can be accepted, mostly around docs.

1) You don't ensure that the ring handoff constraint is reset to 'zone' at the end of the test. This could allow other tests (or future tests) to break if they assume a particular constraint.

2) Thank you for putting in the code comment describing the change. However I think it would be better in a docstring so that it is included in the auto-generated docs.

3) This change needs to be documented in (at least) the admin_guide and deployment_guide.

4) Because you are adding a config option to swift.conf, you should add the default setting (commented out) to the sample config file. See the other sample configs for examples of this."}, {'account_id': 2622, 'date': '2012-03-26 19:56:15.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't submit this

I like the idea of being more flexible in the choice of handoff nodes. However, I'd much prefer if it were automatic instead of configurable.

Essentially, this change as written lets you choose handoff nodes that are as far as possible from the original replicas, but in order to do that, you have to update a configuration file. I'd argue that this could be done automatically: if there are nodes in other zones, then use them; otherwise, if there are nodes on other machines (different IP), then use them; and if there's nothing else, look for other devices in the same machines.

This would make life easier for Swift cluster operators; as their clusters grow, the quality of handoff nodes automatically increases from other-disk to other-ip and finally to other-zone, as the resources become available. There's no possibility of forgetting to update swift.conf and getting other-disk handoffs when there's room in other zones."}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2012-04-03 06:03:15.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

code review expired after 1 week of no activity after a negative review'}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2012-04-03 06:03:17.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Abandoned

code review expired after 1 week of no activity after a negative review'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2012-03-21 13:57:41.000000000', 'message': 'Allow configurable handoff node constraints

See blueprint swift-configurable-handoff-constraints
Load ring_handoff constraint from /etc/swift/swift.conf
 zone : handoff nodes in different zones from primary replicas and
        other handoff nodes. This is the default swift behavior
 ip   : handoff nodes have different IP addresses than primary nodes
        but may be in the same zone as primary nodes or other
        handoffs. This usually implies that the handoff nodes are on
        a different server
 disk : handoff nodes have are on different disk drives than primary
        nodes, but may be on the same server in the same zone as
        primary nodes or other handoff nodes
ip and disk constraints will generate as many handoff nodes are
there are zones.

Example /etc/swift/swift.conf:
[swift-ring]
ring_handoff = ip

Change-Id: I9a0fb8b2c351aca547cb49241de7c4dce67c087c
'}]
commit_message:
Allow configurable handoff node constraints

See blueprint swift-configurable-handoff-constraints
Load ring_handoff constraint from /etc/swift/swift.conf
 zone : handoff nodes in different zones from primary replicas and
        other handoff nodes. This is the default swift behavior
 ip   : handoff nodes have different IP addresses than primary nodes
        but may be in the same zone as primary nodes or other
        handoffs. This usually implies that the handoff nodes are on
        a different server
 disk : handoff nodes have are on different disk drives than primary
        nodes, but may be on the same server in the same zone as
        primary nodes or other handoff nodes
ip and disk constraints will generate as many handoff nodes are
there are zones.

Example /etc/swift/swift.conf:
[swift-ring]
ring_handoff = ip

Change-Id: I9a0fb8b2c351aca547cb49241de7c4dce67c087c

Also, make sure that exceptions within the client are accompanied with
a full stack trace, otherwise it is hard to track down where it happened.
